Traitor","link":"https://www.cbr.com/guardians-of-the-galaxy-moondragon-traitor/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Guardians-of-the-Galaxy-feature-1.jpg\"/></figure><p><strong><em>WARNING: The following contains spoilers for <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/guardians-of-the-galaxy/\">Guardians of the Galaxy</a> #5-6 by Al Ewing, Juann Cabal, Federico Blee, and VC's Cory Petit, on sale now.</em></strong></p><p>When Gamora, Drax and Groot broke away from the group following Star-Lord's death, it wasn't totally clear why their anger forced them against their own teammates. But as <em>Guardians of the Galaxy</em> #5 revealed, the main Marvel Moondragon gave them that mental push to embrace their rage as she was angry the Guardians took in a Phyla-Vell and Moondragon from an alternate reality after <em>Infinity Warps</em>.</p><p>However, with both Moondragons going to war and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/guardians-of-galaxy-moondragon-upgrade/\">fusing as one</a>, while it seems there's peace at least, the Guardians might still actually have their biggest traitor onboard and an enemy they can't trust in the form of one of the universe's most powerful psychics.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/guardians-galaxy-bereet-hulk-history/\">Guardians of the Galaxy: The MCU's Bereet Has a WILD History With the Hulk</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/moondragon.jpg\"/></figure><p>Moondragon 2.0 lives the ideal life and after beating the main Moondragon on the mental plane, she absorbed her essence to form this ultimate Moondragon. She wanted to share her perfection with her broken counterpart, taking the corrupting Dragon of the Moon as an energy ring on her finger. However, it's not entirely clear what Moondragon 2.0 lost in her world, or what other tragedies there she can exploit.</p><p>She might have lost her dad, Arthur Douglas, when she was a kid, Heather, so there's always remnant trauma from that to explore. That means that the Dragon of the Moon or the Marvel Universe Moondragon could always tap into these things and turn the merged Moondragon evil, not unlike Cassandra Nova famously took over the body of Charles Xavier. There's still a chance the main Moondragon could grow bitter again, co-opting Moondragon 2.0 from the inside when she sees how much Phyla-Vell is in love. Moondragon lost her Phyla-Vell to Thanos, and she's never recovered, so seeing this playing out is sure to get to her.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/legion-superheroes-vs-guardians-galaxy-fight/\">Legion Of Superheroes vs. Guardians Of The Galaxy: Who Would Really Win?</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/moondragon-2.jpg\"/></figure><p>We also can't discount that a Dragon of the Moon also resides within the merged Moondragon, and it might not like the new tenants. It could become jealous or see them as threats, leading to another psychic war. If this is the case, the main Moondragon may also look to heal the relationship with Drax, since the merged Moondragon and him seem to have hit it off. Simply put, the outsider came over and took everything from the main Moondragon, so the latter could be playing a long game in an effort to turn Drax into the Destroyer again.</p><p>What makes this possibility so worrying is the sinister Moondragon would know all the Guardians' flaws and weaknesses, and she'd easily know how to fake it with Phyla-Vell by spending time in the alternate's body. In so doing, she can manipulate her teammates with a body that holds much more power and become the ultimate Moondragon, even by seeking revenge on those who moved on while she couldn't. Whether she's using Moondragon's collective tragic past or her own demons, she's co-piloting and could be ready to jump into the driver's seat without the Guardians even realizing what's going on, and she could turn the Marvel team into unwitting pawns in her grand cosmic schemes.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/guardians-of-the-galaxy-hercules-new-boyfriend/\">Guardians of the Galaxy #6 Reveals Hercules' New Boyfriend</a></span></p><p><!-- Used for easily cloning the properly namespaced rect --></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 03:20:22 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Guardians-of-the-Galaxy-feature-1.jpg","linkMd5":"bcec69b52748e6585011f61e72d34d43","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn75@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-30-870_6b58d499d81bcc89.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":227370,"destBytes":227370,"author":"Renaldo Matadeen","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Guardians-of-the-Galaxy-feature-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn75@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-30-870_6b58d499d81bcc89.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/moondragon.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn8@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-35-038_16af04f647332ab6.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/moondragon-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn35@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-40-331_7ce525778b5b62f5.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989060},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"10 Of The Craziest Things To Happen In Ultimate Spider-Man, Ranked","link":"https://www.cbr.com/craziest-things-in-marvel-ultimate-spider-man/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Ultimate-Spider-Man-cover-photo.jpg\"/></figure><p>At a time when <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/spider-man/\">Spider-Man</a> stories became more and more controversial with <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-spider-man-90s-clone-saga-bad-good/\">stories such as the original</a> <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/clone-saga/\">clone saga</a>, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/marvel/\">Marvel</a> introduced the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/ultimate-spider-man/\">Ultimate Spider-Man</a> with the arrival of the new <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/ultimate-marvel/\">Ultimate Universe</a>. This provided a much needed reboot to his story with a wide variety of changes.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-alternate-reality-spiderman-better-worse-original/\">Marvel: 5 Alternate Reality Spider-Men Better Than The Original (&#38; 5 That Are Worse)</a></span></p><p>These included his origins, villains, family, and plenty of other aspects from the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/marvel-616/\">Earth 616's </a>Spider-Man that fans have been accustomed to. While he was definitely not the only Marvel character to be changed in the Ultimate Universe, he definitely was one of the ones to be so drastically changed and here are some of the craziest things to happen.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>Introduction Of Miles Morales</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Miles-Morales.jpg' /></figure><p>While this does not initially seem like a crazy occurrence, at the time it was unexpected that they would give us <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/miles-morales-facts/\">a new Spider-Man</a>, especially considering that he surfaced after Spider-Man's death. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/miles-morales/\">Miles Morales</a> is praised by many to be a more relatable Spider-Man due to his background and upbringing. As far as family is concerned, he has his parents as well as plenty of close friends to help him out along the way. Not to mention he is more spider-like in some ways such as the design of his costume and with his a wide variety of different powers such as invisibility and venom blast.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Miles' Uncle As The Prowler</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Miles-and-Prowler.jpg' /></figure><p>Speaking of his family, Miles' uncle Aaron Davis is none other than the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/prowler/\">Prowler</a>. He proves to be a stark contrast to Peter's <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/uncle-ben/\">Uncle Ben</a> and far from a role model for Miles'. He even goes so far as to force Miles to help him <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/spider-man-facts-trivia-scorpion/\">take down</a> <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/scorpion/\">Scorpion</a>, who is a gang leader in this universe.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-characters-define-next-era-comics-kamala-khan-gwen-stacy-miles-morales/\">10 Marvel Characters That Could Define The Next Era In Comics</a></span></p><p>To make matters worse, the Prowler attacks Miles after he refuses to work with him further, though this ultimately results in Aaron's death. This change definitely adds more depth to the Prowler in how he is connected to Miles, showing him how not to act.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Kraven The Hunter - Reality TV Star</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Kraven-Ultimate-Universe.jpg' /></figure><p>In one of the weirder changes, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/kraven-the-hunter/\">Kraven The Hunter</a>, one of Spider-Man's fiercer foes who <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-spider-man-worst-things-kraven-the-hunter-did/\">even killed and replaced him</a> on one occasion in <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/kravens-last-hunt/\"><em>Kraven's Last Hunt</em></a>, is a reality television star. With this, he decided to hunt Spider-Man purely to boost the ratings of his show. However, he was defeated with a single punch from the web slinger due to him just being a normal guy. Despite this, he would later genetically enhance himself <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-sinister-six-worst-things/\">when joining the</a> <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/sinister-six/\">Sinister Six</a>, more closely resembling the Kraven from Earth-616 that fans know and love.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Wolverine And Spider-Man Switch Bodies</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Wolverine-Spider-Man-Ultimate-Universe.jpg' /></figure><p>While Spider-Man and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/wolverine/\">Wolverine</a> have not often seen eye to eye on many things, there is an increased animosity between the two in the Ultimate Universe. Matters are made even worse when the two realize they have switched bodies with one another. During this time, Wolverine even <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-mary-jane-ultimate-classic/\">hits on</a> <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/mary-jane-watson/\">Mary Jane</a> at one point. As for Spider-Man, he was quickly discovered due to his much more gentle nature and joking demeanor.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-ultimate-spider-man-parker-similarities-differences/\">Ultimate Spider-Man: 5 Ways He's The Same As The Regular Version (&#38; 5 Ways He's Totally Different)</a></span></p><p>The two are most definitely stark contrasts to one another and this shows in how they act in the others skin. It is eventually <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-jean-grey-best-mutant-worst/\">revealed that</a> <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/jean-grey/\">Jean Grey</a> did it because she was tired of Wolverine hitting on her and wanted to put him in the body of the last person he'd want to be in.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Venom As A Cure For Cancer</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Venom-Ultimate-Spider-Man.jpg' /></figure><p>Eddie Brock, unlike his Earth-616 counterpart, is a childhood friend of Peter Parker who grew up to be very close to him. Their parents, Richard Parker and Eddie Brock Sr. worked together on \"The Suit\" which was designed to heal peoples' bodies upon attaching to it. The suit was even supposed cure diseases such as cancer. Peter tried it out, transforming into the black suited Spider-Man, and realized the dangerous potential of the substance. From that point, he tried to destroy it, but Eddie Brock took it and became <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/venom/\">Venom</a> in spite of this. This version of Venom is a prime example of good intentions gone wrong and with their history, he serves as a much more sympathetic character.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Aunt May's Character</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Aunt-May-Ultimate-Universe.jpg' /></figure><p>Another character that is changed for the better in this new universe is none other <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/spider-man-best-worst-aunt-may-versions/\">than Peter's</a> <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/aunt-may/\">Aunt May</a>. In the original comics, she can tend to be a bit more of a damsel in distress more times than not. Conversely, her Ultimate Universe counterpart is much more fierce and upfront though still just as caring in her own different ways.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/ultimate-spider-man-character-changes-good-bad/\">5 Ways Ultimate Spider-Man Improved The Character (&#38; 5 It Ruined Him)</a></span></p><p>In fact, she even ends up shooting <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/electro/\">Electro</a> three times with her revolver before he can get the killing blow on Peter just moments after hearing he is in danger.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Spider-Man's Origins</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Spider-Mans-origins-Ultimate-Spider-Man.jpg' /></figure><p>While this encompasses a wide variety of different changes, these are nonetheless big, wild changes in regards to his the widely accepted origin story at the time. For starters, he got his powers on a trip to <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/oscorp-industries/\">Oscorp</a> which gave him more of a connection to <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/norman-osborn/\">Norman Osborn</a>. Additionally, the spider was not radioactive, but did contain the OZ formula which would have some more unexpected effects.</p><p>As far as his relationships go, not only does Mary Jane appear much earlier than in the original comics, but Peter also tells her very early on that he is Spider-Man. This is huge as it was kept such a huge secret from everyone around him, especially Mary Jane in the Earth-616 universe. Additionally, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/spiderman-best-worst-versions-uncle-ben/\">Uncle Ben is around much longer</a> before his death and with this the relationship between Peter and himself is much more developed.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Carnage's Creation</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Carnage-Ultimate-Spider-Man.jpg' /></figure><p>Similar to Venom, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/carnage/\">Carnage</a> came about in a very different way in <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/spiderman-carnage-best-versions/\">the Ultimate Universe</a>. To create it, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/curt-connors/\">Doc Connors</a> uses his genetic materials as well as Spider-Man's blood. As a result, Carnage wanted to be Peter and used his DNA to complete his form. Similar to his Earth-616 counterpart, this form was a hellish version of Peter.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-comics-peter-parker-spider-man-ultimate-616/\">5 Things Ultimate Spider-Man Did Great (&#38; 5 Things 616 Did Better)</a></span></p><p>To add insult to injury, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/character-changes-marvel-ultimate-universe-didnt-last/\">Carnage even kills</a> <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/gwen-stacy/\">Gwen Stacy</a> and absorbs her into it in gruesome fashion. Although Gwen Stacy was eventually brought back, permanently free of Carnage, it was still a shocking twist of fate for the character in the first place.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>A Very Different Green Goblin</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Green-Goblin-Ultimate-Universe.jpg' /></figure><p>The Ultimate <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/green-goblin/\">Green Goblin</a>, noted by many as one of the best variations of the character, has his <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/ultimate-green-goblin-different-classic-same/\">fair share of differences</a> from the original Norman Osborn. For instance, he underwent a mutation which turned him into a big, hulking, demonic monster contrary to Earth-616 where he wears a suit. The mutation also gives him incredible strength as well as fire powers. In this universe, he is also the leader of the Sinister Six. With this and their shared connection, Green Goblin cements himself early on as Peter's arch enemy.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Death of Spider-Man</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Death-of-Spider-Man.jpg' /></figure><p>In what has to be the most shocking event of the series, Spider-Man meets his end at the hands of Green Goblin and other villains. This proves to be a much more gruesome, sad death than many of his others throughout comic book history. For starters, he takes a bullet for <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/captain-america/\">Captain America</a>, injuring himself for the fight that is to come. This is also when Aunt May shoots Electro, sadly only barely delaying Spider-Man's death.</p><p>The story sees him face off against Green Goblin and the Sinister Six, the former of which deals the killing blow. In an epic battle between the Goblin and Spider-Man, they each deal the killing blow to the other. Although they both would eventually come back, this death was emotional as Peter spoke of how he was able to save his family and friends this time where he couldn't save Uncle Ben.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/spider-man-deaths-ranked/\">How Many Times Has Spider-Man Died? Ranking Every Death (&#38; Almost Death) In The Spider-Verse</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 02:00:03 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Ultimate-Spider-Man-cover-photo.jpg","linkMd5":"7716f0b0242eeed4c3afaa47389cfd8c","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn90@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-29-182_025f59b3419afb5a.webp","destWidth":1710,"destHeight":900,"sourceBytes":295588,"destBytes":295588,"author":"Danny Damico","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Ultimate-Spider-Man-cover-photo.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn90@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-29-182_025f59b3419afb5a.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Miles-Morales.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn8@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-35-667_a7398ea4f8ec81d5.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Miles-and-Prowler.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn61@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-42-970_94a9e98e8ebffb79.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Kraven-Ultimate-Universe.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn74@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-42-278_9f08209d062d0f4d.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Wolverine-Spider-Man-Ultimate-Universe.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn18@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-33-999_b4625761a6c65407.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Venom-Ultimate-Spider-Man.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn55@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-35-365_99f31535e0e1ccf1.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Aunt-May-Ultimate-Universe.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn34@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-34-127_973c6f7d797d0f93.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Spider-Mans-origins-Ultimate-Spider-Man.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn92@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-44-050_98544b73fd9178e3.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Carnage-Ultimate-Spider-Man.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn41@2020_1/2020/09/05/06-56-34-063_cdeb8a848a4c1d5c.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Green-Goblin-Ultimate-Universe.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn82@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-38-502_c055ad42136822c5.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Death-of-Spider-Man.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn20@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-41-066_064d38c525529fdd.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989064},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Lovecraft Country: How Letitia's Haunted House May Connect to the Author's Mythos","link":"https://www.cbr.com/lovecraft-country-holy-ghost-haunted-house-connection-mythos/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/lovecraft-country-2.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><strong>WARNING: The following contains major spoilers for <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/lovecraft-country/\">Lovecraft Country</a> Season 1, Episode 3, \"Holy Ghost,\" which aired Sunday on HBO.</strong></em></p><p>In the first two episodes of <em>Lovecraft Country</em>, Atticus, his uncle George and his friend Letitia went to Ardham, Massachusetts, in search of Montrose Freeman. While they eventually found Tic's missing father, they got roped up in a conspiracy that involved the Order of the Ancient Dawn and a group of white men who called themselves the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lovecraft-country-why-sons-adam-ritual-failed/\">Sons of Adam</a>. These men were led by Samuel Braithwaite, a wizard who planned on using Atticus to open a door to the Garden of Eden. After <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lovecraft-country-sons-of-adams-true-mastermind/\">Samuel's plans were thwarted</a>, Tic, Letitia and Montrose returned home following <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lovecraft-country-episode-2-atticus-reunite-montrose-kills-off-george/\">George's tragic death</a>.</p><p>In the latest episode, \"Holy Ghost,\" Leti receives a large inheritance, which is secretly from Christina Braithwaite, and buys a house in an all-white neighborhood. However, the house is actually haunted by ghosts. But while the episode and its terrors are mostly self-contained, \"Holy Ghost\" may have a major connection to the larger Lovecraft mythos at the heart of the HBO series.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lovecraft-country-atticus-george-montrose-real-father-question/\">Lovecraft Country: Atticus May Not Be Who We Think He Is</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Lovecraft-Country-Letitia-header.jpeg\"/></figure><p>Shortly after moving into the Winthrop house, Leti realizes it's haunted by the ghosts of several mutilated Black people. She then dives into research about the history of her house, eventually learning Winthrop was a member of the Sons of Adam before he was eventually kicked out of the group. What's more, the house then belonged to a man named Hiram Epstein, a white scientist who experimented on African Americans inside his home. But Epstein wasn't just any old type of scientist -- he was an astrophysicist. Given that his field of study relates to the stars, it seems very strange that he performed torturous experiments on people, since his goals weren't medical or anything of the like.</p><p>Given Winthrop and Epstein's connections to the Sons of Adam, it's possible their experiments were done in the name of the Order of the Ancient Dawn's cosmic goals. Either they too were searching for a means to open the gates to the Garden of Eden, or perhaps their goals stretched even further than that.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lovecraft-country-introduces-different-horror/\">Lovecraft Country Reveals a VERY Different Kind of Horror</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Lovecraft-Country-Order-of-the-Ancient-Dawn.jpg\"/></figure><p><em>Lovecraft Country</em> obviously draws from author H.P. Lovecraft's mythology. The series premiere alone featured an appearance <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lovecraft-country-series-premiere-cthulhu-debut-dream-sequence/\">from Cthulhu</a> (in a dream), as well as the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lovecraft-country-series-premiere-shoggoth-explainer/\">monstrous Shoggoth</a>. The second episode of the series also mentioned the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lovecraft-country-necronomicon-explainer/\">Necronomicon</a>, a book that is said to contain spells meant to summon the Old Ones, ancient, god-like aliens who once ruled the Earth. Since Epstein was an astrophysicist and Winthrop was a member of the Sons of Adam, it's possible their experiments were connected to rituals meant to summon the Old Ones.</p><p>Now that Leti has helped the ghosts in her house find peace, perhaps she will learn more about the Winthrop house's previous owners, and its connection to the Sons of Adam -- and, by extension, Atticus.</p><p><em>Starring Jonathan Majors, Jurnee Smollett, Aunjanue Ellis, Abbey Lee, Jada Harris, Wunmi Mosaku and Michael K. Williams, Lovecraft Country airs Sundays at 9 p.m. ET/PT on HBO.</em></p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/birds-of-prey-jurnee-smollett-lost-muscles/\">Birds of Prey: Jurnee Smollett Had to Lose Her Black Canary Muscles for Lovecraft Country</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 18:45:29 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/lovecraft-country-2.jpg","linkMd5":"ad63f2b8532dca79813ce6677e760b56","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn33@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-29-196_d4de17577bd7afba.webp","destWidth":1200,"destHeight":600,"sourceBytes":99148,"destBytes":99148,"author":"Ian Cardona","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/lovecraft-country-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn33@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-29-196_d4de17577bd7afba.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Lovecraft-Country-Letitia-header.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn72@2020_1/2020/09/05/06-56-36-821_06c71989ebf5651d.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Lovecraft-Country-Order-of-the-Ancient-Dawn.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn25@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-34-027_d8d8a15caa64ee49.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989073},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Spider-Man and Silk: How Peter Parker and Cindy Moon Are Connected","link":"https://www.cbr.com/spider-man-silk-peter-parker-cindy-moon-link/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Spider-Man-Silk.jpg\"/></figure><p>Although a majority of the Spider-People that roam the multiverse received their powers from the same kind of radioactive spider bite that empowered <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/spider-man\">Spider-Man</a>, there are also many Spider-based heroes that gained their powers in vastly different situations, especially within the main Marvel Universe. Heroes, like <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/without-peter-parker-spider-woman-lead-sony-spider-verse/\">Spider-Woman</a> and Spider-Girl, found their origins in secret government experiments and mystical societies. These different sources of spider-powers gave each Spider-hero their own set of abilities and worlds to protect. However, one hero shared both the same origin as Peter Parker, and she was bitten by the exact same spider. And that's how Cindy Moon was transformed into the hero Silk.</p><p>During the events of <em>Original Sin</em>, the Watcher's eyes, taken after his brutal murder, began to unleash the many secrets that Uatu had witnessed throughout the universe, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/what-nick-fury-whispered-thor-unworthy/\">secrets that even cut down gods</a>. Peter Parker learned of the secret history of Cindy Moon, a girl who was bitten on the same radioactive spider before it drew its last breath. As seen in the pages of 2014's <em>Amazing Spider-Man #</em>4, by Dan Slott and Humberto Ramos, Peter saw how her inability to control her powers led Ezekiel Sims to discover her presence. Warning her of Morlun and his family of Inheritors, he convinced Cindy to remain hidden in a secret bunker, concealing her existence from the rest of the world.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/sony-multiple-marvel-series-silk/\">Sony Developing Netflix-Style 'Suite' of Marvel Series, Starting With Silk</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Silk-Original-Suit.jpg\"/></figure><p>When Cindy emerged after years of boredom, she was at first enraged and excited by the prospect. After Peter opened the bunker, she at first responded by attacking the man that had made her sacrifice worthless, as Morlun was then able to detect her presence. Peter saw firsthand how Silk's powers differed from his own. Shooting barb-tipped webs from her fingertips, Cindy possessed far greater speed than Peter at the cost of being slightly weaker. Additionally, Cindy was far more attuned to her Spider-Sense, giving her better reflexes in battle.</p><p>Due to sharing the same spider, Peter and Cindy share a rather complex relationship. Upon releasing her, Peter came to realize that Cindy was, at one point, destined to replace him. However, he lost this chance to stop being Spider-Man when he decided to continue being a hero. Cindy was well-aware of her potential as a hero and as the future head of the proverbial Spider-Family. The two were also extremely attracted to each other, thanks to pheromones that came from being bitten by the same spider. This created, in Peter's words, \"the urge to mate like spider-bunnies.\" Aside from this awkward situation, Peter worked to ensure that Cindy could restart her life, following years of isolation.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/spider-man-ends-of-the-earth-guide/\">Ends of the Earth: A Complete Guide to Spider-Man's Sinister Six Epic</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/silk-header.jpg\"/></figure><p>Cindy's biggest role was during the events of the original \"<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/spider-verse/\">Spider-Verse</a>\" where she also donned a new costume. Sensing the pending arrival of the Inheritors, she attempted to hide Peter himself and take the lead. When this didn't come to pass, Cindy found herself a central role in the conflict as the Bride, one of the most powerful and important Spider-Totems to their enemy. Working with Spider-Woman and Spider-Man Noir, Cindy went on the run, but her inexperience in battle would eventually lead to her capture. After the Spider-forces freed her, Cindy would, in return, save Peter Parker in his confrontation with Morlun. After this battle, Cindy was completely free and able to pursue her own life.</p><p>In her civilian life, Cindy took a job at the Fact Channel, using the company's resources to track down her missing family that had disappeared in her time away. Silk continued to fight crime, even going undercover to take on the Black Cat's criminal organization. Currently, she serves as a member of the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/agents-of-atlas/\">Agents of the Atlas</a>, having joined the team during the <em>War of the Realms</em>. Although she has joined the larger superhero community, Silk continues to come to Peter's aid whenever he needs it. When the Red Goblin attacked Peter's family, he relied on Cindy's help to save his loved ones. Now, with the rise of Kindred, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/amazing-spider-man-miles-morales-team/\">Cindy is sure to return to Peter's side</a> to help in his greatest battle yet.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/spider-man-sin-eater-targets-green-goblin/\">Spider-Man: Sin-Eater's Next Target Is a MAJOR Marvel Villain</a></span></p><p><!-- Used for easily cloning the properly namespaced rect --></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 18:20:44 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Spider-Man-Silk.jpg","linkMd5":"294ee8cc68cba9ac60aa84adb207f3a0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn29@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-31-161_c56a8dd2f27a611a.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":138178,"destBytes":138178,"author":"Paul Yang","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Spider-Man-Silk.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn29@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-31-161_c56a8dd2f27a611a.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Silk-Original-Suit.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn15@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-40-256_3e640cc304775dd9.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/silk-header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn12@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-39-517_30363bffc2a1b197.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989074},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"John Ridley Addresses the 'Black Heroes With Electrical Powers' Trope ","link":"https://www.cbr.com/john-ridley-black-heroes-electrical-powers-trope/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/OUTSIDERS-Black-Lightning.jpg\"/></figure><p>With the first issue of the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/dc-black-label/\">DC Black Label</a> series <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-other-history-of-the-dc-universe/\">The Other History of the DC Universe</a></em> showcasing Black Lightning -- DC's first Black hero to lead his own title -- writer John Ridley mused about the trope of Black superheroes having electricity-based powers.</p><p>Ridley spoke to <a href=\"https://www.polygon.com/comics/2020/9/3/21408118/dc-comics-alternate-history-other-black-lightning-john-ridley-interview\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Polygon</a>, which noted that DC characters <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/black-lightning/\">Black Lightning</a> and Static, as well as the Marvel characters Storm and the Miles Morales Spider-Man, have such abilities in common. Also in the fraternity: Black Lightning's daughter Lightning, the Jackson Hyde Aqualad and Black Vulcan -- a Black Lightning knock-off created for the 1970s animated series <em>Super Friends</em>.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/john-ridley-why-other-history-dc-universe-begins-black-lightning/\">John Ridley Explains Why The Other History of the DC Universe Begins With Black Lightning</a></span></p><p>\"You know, it's weird,\" said Ridley. \"Because I'd read that somewhere previously and it was one of those things you go, 'Wow, yeah, that is kind of weird.' And it's not one of those things where you can, at least to me, draw a line and go, 'Oh, well' — like the way Asian characters are usually going to have karate-related powers. And for a long time you went 'OK, sure, why not?' And you look at it now and go, 'Well, yeah, why couldn’t an Asian individual have these kinds of powers or those kinds of powers,' and certainly they can.\"</p><p>He then pointed out where the comparison fails, saying, \"But with lightning powers, it's not — at least in an way that I could look at and go, 'Oh, well, this goes back to something in the culture,' or something in storytelling that became a trope for perhaps the wrong reasons or perhaps overly identifiable reasons.\"</p><p>Ridley didn't draw a definitive conclusion, although he noted, \"It’s certainly nothing in particular that I look at as a person of color and go, 'Oh, man, people have been doing that and it’s wrong because it leads to this, this or this.'.... I don’t take it as something overly negative. It does seem to be a weird happenstance. But it may be a deeper dive for a broader thinker.\"</p><p>Ridley won the Oscar for Best Adapted Screenplay for <em>12 Years a Slave</em> in 2014. He's written for the animated shows <em>Static Shock</em> and <em>Justice League</em>, and his comics work includes <em>The American Way</em> for WildStorm and sequel <em>The American Way: Those Above and Those Below</em> for Vertigo.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/john-ridley-other-history-of-the-dc-universe-black-label-series-release-date/\">John Ridley's The Other History of the DC Universe Black Label Series Announces Release Date</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 23:44:28 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/OUTSIDERS-Black-Lightning.jpg","linkMd5":"86aa8dfb0337f2898f13361505a3e21a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn2@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-31-730_a19f0ce0b4e0d8c0.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":175160,"destBytes":175160,"author":"Kelvin Childs","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/OUTSIDERS-Black-Lightning.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn2@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-31-730_a19f0ce0b4e0d8c0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989066},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Game of Thrones: Maisie Williams Reveals the Night King's Original Killer","link":"https://www.cbr.com/game-of-thrones-maisie-williams-night-kings-original-killer/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/episode-3-arya2.jpg\"/></figure><p>Though <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/game-of-thrones/\">Game of Thrones</a></em>' final season was fairly divisive among fans, one of the most talked-about scenes featured Arya Stark (Maisie Williams) delivering a fatal blow to the Night King. However, Williams says that she expected a different character to end the threat of the White Walkers.</p><p>\"[Kit Harrington] expected it to go [Jon Snow’s] way, too, and he even said, 'It was going to go that way. Someone told me in season three that I was going to kill The Night King,'\" Williams said during an interview.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/three-body-problem-game-of-thrones-creators-netflix-adaptation/\">The Three-Body Problem: Game of Thrones Creators Board Netflix Adaptation</a></span></p><p>\"And then, he read the script, and it was Arya the whole time,\" she continued with a laugh. \"Yeah, I think it would’ve been too obvious. I’m glad that it was Arya, honestly. I think I had the best storyline of the final season.\"</p><p>Williams has been fairly busy post-<em>Game of Thrones</em>. Her current projects include the black comedy series <em>Two Weeks to Live</em> and the horror film <em>The Owners</em>. Williams also played a key role in <em>The New Mutants</em> as lycanthropic mutant Rahne Sinclair, code named Wolfsbane. The film is currently in theaters.</p><p><em>Game of Thrones</em> stars Peter Dinklage, Nikolaj Coster-Waldau, Lena Headey, Emilia Clarke, Sophie Turner, Maisie Williams and Kit Harington. The <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/game-of-thrones-4k-collection-preorder/\">4K UHD collection</a> will be released on Nov. 3.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/game-of-thrones-emilia-clarke-sexist-double-standard-female-castmembers/\">Game of Thrones' Emilia Clarke Slams Sexist Double Standard in How Female Castmembers Were Treated</a></span></p><p>(via <em><a href=\"https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/maisie-williams-on-the-owners-and-the-original-night-king-ending-on-games-of-thrones\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Hollywood Reporter</a></em>)</p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 22:26:49 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/episode-3-arya2.jpg","linkMd5":"fc3c4e3b4d123e7597427f18d8774854","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn56@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-30-705_5f1a399adb181c37.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":159125,"destBytes":109832,"author":"Collier Jennings","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/04/episode-3-arya2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn56@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-30-705_5f1a399adb181c37.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989067},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"I Am a Hero: How the Zombie Manga Perfects Slow-Burn Horror | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/i-am-a-hero-zombie-manga-slow-burn-horror/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/i-am-a-hero.jpg\"/></figure><p>Slow-burn horror builds suspense, often teasing the prolonging the threat of something terrible happening while withholding its true nature. If done right, slow-burn horror can provide a terrific payoff to the audience. Manga, with its tendency to luxuriate in slower pacing, can shock a reader with the turn of a page. One series in particular blends slow-burn horror and intricately detailed artwork to become the \"greatest zombie manga ever\": Kengo Hanazawa's <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/i-am-a-hero/\">I Am a Hero</a></em>.</p><p>Published from 2009 to 2017, across 22 volumes,<em> I Am a Hero</em> centers on manga art assistant Hideo Suzuki, who dreams of becoming a successful artist even while his proposals are repeatedly rejected. Not helping matters is that his job is exhausting and low-paying, and his girlfriend is unfaithful. Then, one day, while going practice shooting with his hunting shotgun, Hideo finds himself in the midst of a zombie apocalypse.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/into-the-spider-verse-peni-parker-deserves-her-own-anime/\">Into the Spider-Verse: Peni Parker Deserves Her Own Anime</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/I-am-a-hero-apartment.jpg\"/></figure><p>The dance that Hideo Suzuki performs when he enters his apartment tells us that something isn't quite right with him. Even more unsettling is the hallucinations that he experiences: Arms sprout out from the blinds next to his bed, and he can see a face peering out at him from the peephole in his door. Hideo's strange antics set the tone for the manga as twisted with a sense of humor. The claustrophobic nature of Hideo's apartment heightens the tense atmosphere we've been thrust into, and that's just the start.</p><p>Hideo surrounds himself with manga and holds his shotgun before dosing off. The next morning, his TV turns on, and we are informed of what is being claimed as an arson attack on a senior home. Before Hideo switches the channel, the reporter says, \"In addition to burns on the corpses...\" We are left to imagine what else the reporter had to say, but we can guess that it would be something along the lines of \"bite marks on the corpses.\"</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-misfit-of-demon-king-academy-episode-8-sheilas-salvation/\">The Misfit of Demon King Academy Reveals the Key To Sheila's Salvation</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/i-am-a-hero-zombie.jpg\"/></figure><p>All throughout the first half of the first volume, there is the sense of impending chaos; incidents are commented upon and reported about in the background. Even Hideo's coworkers, while maintaining a level of normalcy in their daily lives, can't help but gossip about sudden attacks on people, with most of them involving being bitten.</p><p>The first glimpse we get of an actual zombie is when Hideo visits his girlfriend after work. On the way, he notices a large, scary tree, and then witnesses a car crash. To his horror, as well as that of other onlookers, the person hit by the vehicle gets up and walks away, her neck snapped backward and her mangled leg trailing behind. Even worse is we hear that bystanders who tried to help were bitten by the victim.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/i-am-a-hero-apocalypse.jpg\"/></figure><p>Eventually, Hideo learns that his girlfriend, Tekko, has become infected with a disease the government dubs ZQN, which causes people to become homicidal. After Hideo does away with Tekko, all hell breaks loose, albeit in a way where, in one part of town, people will literally be eaten on one side, and other people will nonchalantly comment on the events happening before them and carry on with their day on the other side.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-god-of-high-school-mira-fighting-solo-episode-9-clip/\">The God of High School: Mira's Fighting Solo in Exclusive Episode 9 Clip</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/i-am-a-hero-tekko-zombie.jpg\"/></figure><p><em>I Am a Hero</em> is slow with the way it presents its horror. The series knows to show and not tell, and it is through overheard conversations that Hideo -- and, thus, the reader -- learns the world is about to change, mostly for the worse. When the zombie apocalypse that we were promised on the book's cover comes to pass, it's tremendously rewarding.</p><p>An example of that is when Hideo learns that Tekko has become infected with ZQN. While crossing the bridge on the way to her apartment, he notices military vehicles are driving beneath; it's  an indication that, yes, something terrible is about to happen. Hideo ascends the staircase and peeks through the mail slot of Tekko's apartment door. The point of view switches to Hideo's view from the mail slot, and we see Tekko in bed. She sits up, despite Hideo's insistence that she not bother herself. She seems unaware of his pleas, and crawls out of her bed. As she gets closer to the door, the tension ratchets up to a fever pitch, before she reveals her face in all its disheveled glory.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\"><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/how-fist-of-the-north-star-perfected-manly-tears/\">RELATED: Boys DO Cry: How Fist of the North Star Perfected ‘Manly Tears’</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/i-am-a-hero-hideo-vs-tekko.jpg\"/></figure><p><em>I Am a Hero</em> is a zombie manga masterpiece. By making the reader empathize with each character and detailing their struggles, the horror is increased tenfold. Instead of plunging us headfirst into the zombie apocalypse, we are guided into the life of Hideo Suzuki, before seeing the world around him slowly be ripped apart in grizzly fashion. Because of this unconventional style of portraying the zombie apocalypse, it may very well be \"the greatest zombie manga ever.\"</p><p><em>I Am a Hero was published in 2009, and has a total of 22 volumes.</em></p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING:<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/burn-the-witch-dragons-hollows-explained/\"> Burn the Witch: Dragons, the Hollows of Reverse London, Explained</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 22:00:50 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/i-am-a-hero.jpg","linkMd5":"1b32ab8c1942b6c3d284aa478e7b3a01","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn49@2020_1/2020/09/05/06-56-29-318_ba7073d771691c75.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":158708,"destBytes":158708,"author":"Marcus Jones","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/i-am-a-hero.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn49@2020_1/2020/09/05/06-56-29-318_ba7073d771691c75.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/I-am-a-hero-apartment.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn40@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-35-242_9a0d8e2060585c11.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/i-am-a-hero-zombie.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn91@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-36-655_0a7b2a83c2d5c6ba.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/i-am-a-hero-apocalypse.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn99@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-36-513_4df1caddb1359e0b.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/i-am-a-hero-tekko-zombie.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn46@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-34-029_466799e9eb1ed260.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/i-am-a-hero-hideo-vs-tekko.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn69@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-41-471_11fa381a32d389cc.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989068},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"DC: 10 Weird Facts About Power Girl | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/power-girl-weird-facts/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Power-Girl.jpg\"/></figure><p>Power Girl is one of the most interesting and confusing DC Comics characters. Her history stretches back the the 1970s and during several decades in publication and, as a result of several different DC story events such as <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/forgotten-cameos-1985-crisis-infinite-earths/\">Crisis on Infinite Earths</a>, Power Girl’s origins and power set have changed several times.</p><p style=\"text-align: left;\"><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/arrowverse-reasons-power-girl-should-added-franchise-left-out/\">Arrowverse: 5 Reasons Power Girl Should Be Added To The Franchise (&#38; 5 She Shouldn’t Be)</a></span></p><p>The character has, however, recently settled into something a set character. However, while the character has been settled recently there is still a vast history across decades that is full of weird and wonderful facts and stories about Power Girl.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>Earth 2</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Power-Girl-1.jpg' /></figure><p>Despite the fact that Power Girl’s origin has changed somewhat over the years, one of the most consistent elements is that Power Girl is from Earth 2 in the DC Universe. Due to some cosmic event, Power Girl ended up being transferred to Earth 1 and just stayed there.</p><p>The creators of the character wanted to highlight that she was <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dceu-comic-stories-supergirl-film/\">different from Supergirl</a>. While the Girl of Steel is called Kara Zor-El, Power Girl is known as Kara Zor-L.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Descendant Of Atlantian (11 Secret Origins)</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/pjimage-3-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>This list has already pointed out that Power Girl’s origins have changed several times. During the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-infinite-crisis-vs-crisis-on-infinite-earths/\">Crisis on Infinite Earths storyline</a>, much of the DC continuity was rewritten to streamline character backstories and to reset the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-universe-most-important-locations/\">DC Universe</a>.</p><p>In issue 11 of a comic called <em>Secret Origins</em>, Power Girl’s origin was also altered again slightly to give her an Atlantian ancestor. Like many comic book characters, she (and her backstory) have been changed time and again by this point in her canon, but the Atlantean ancestry seems to have stuck around. For now.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Magic pregnancy</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Power-Girl.jpg' /></figure><p>Comic history is incredibly strange in places. One of these very odd stories also occurred to Power Girl. Power Girl was once made magically pregnant by an Atlantian sorcerer (also Power Girl’s grandfather), so that a baby could be born capable of defeating an Atlantian demon.</p><p><p style=\"text-align: left;\"><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-power-girl-surprising-powers/\">DC: 10 Powers You Didn't Know Power Girl Had</a></span></p></p><p>Not only is the story a strange cast of incest, but it also led to the birth of a character known as Equinox - someone who would be forgotten by much of the DC Universe.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Superman 670 - Not Weak To Kryptonite</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Kryptonite.jpg' /></figure><p>Superman, and Kryptonians in general, have many weaknesses but perhaps their most <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/superman-kryptonite-types-effects/\">iconic of which is kryptonite</a>. The weakness is so iconic that it is now commonly understood that when someone says ‘x is my Kryptonite’, anyone will know they’re referring to their weakness.</p><p>However, despite being a Kryptonian, issue 670 of <em>Superman</em> showed that Power Girl isn’t damaged or affected by the Kryptonite radiation.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Stan Lee Didn’t Like Power Girl</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/stan-lee-1.jpg' /></figure><p>Stan Lee is one of the most important figures in comic book history. Stan Lee helped turn <a href=\"https://screenrant.com/tag/Marvel\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Marvel</a> into the powerhouse it is today, helping to create Spider-Man, the X-Men, and Iron Man. What is interesting to note is that Stan Lee really didn’t like Power Girl.</p><p>The reasoning behind this comes from the time that Marvel was sued by DC after introducing a character known as Wonder Man, saying it was too close to Wonder Woman. However, Marvel had a Power Man character, so Stan Lee was really not happy that DC wasn’t forced to stop Power Girl.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Objectification</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Power-Girl.jpg' /></figure><p>It’s no secret that women in comics are often objectified far more than their male counterparts. Very rarely does a male superhero have as much skin showing as the likes of Wonder Woman or Power Girl. However, Power Girl’s objectification goes far deeper.</p><p><p style=\"text-align: left;\"><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-power-girl-most-ridiculous-feats-strength-ranked-power/\">Power Girl’s 10 Most Ridiculous Feats Of Strength, Ranked</a></span></p></p><p>Power Girl is often objectified in the comics too with the Flash having made creepy comments in the past. Furthermore, one of the artists on <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/awesome-power-girl-cosplays/\">Power Girl</a> said he would make her breasts bigger every issue until the editors told him to stop.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Kara Star CEO</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/08/Power-Girl.jpg' /></figure><p>In one comic, Power Girl and Huntress ended up falling into Earth Zero. In order to survive in this universe, Power Girl and Huntress adapted to life in different ways. Huntress would rely on stealing from Wayne Entreprises to survive, but Power Girl would form her own business and become CEO.</p><p>The position as CEO gave her both fame and influence, allowing her to improve the lives of those around her with her resources and wealth.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Mr Terrific</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Mr-Terrific.jpg' /></figure><p>One of James Bond’s most prevalent characteristics is his willingness to seduce women in order to gain secrets or access to a particular location. As if mirroring Bond, this is exactly what Power Girl did.</p><p>While acting as CEO Kara Star, Power Girl seduced Mr. Terrific so that she could learn the secrets of his company and the technology he possessed.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Harley Quinn</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Power-Girl-Harley-Quinn.jpeg' /></figure><p>Sidekicks are some of the most memorable parts of superhero comics. Batman obviously has the most famous sidekick in Robin, but in the past Superman has had Superboy, Aquaman has had Aqualad, and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/harley-quinn-solo-team-character-better-worse/\">Power Girl had Harley Quinn</a>?</p><p><p style=\"text-align: left;\"><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-supergirl-vs-power-girl-who-would-win/\">DC: Supergirl Vs Power Girl: Who Would Win?</a></span></p></p><p>In a recent comic, Harley Quinn ended up tricking Power Girl into believing that she was her sidekick, going on a cosmic, whacky adventure with Power Girl in the process.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Natural Elements </h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/01/Power-Girl-Incapacitated-By-Wood-in-Supergirl.jpg' /></figure><p>One of the points of this list was that Power Girl is immune to kryptonite. While this may appear to hold her in good stead, it doesn’t actually mean that she has no weaknesses at all. In fact, her weakness is far worse than kryptonite.</p><p>Power Girl is weak to ‘natural elements’ that are ‘raw and unprocessed’. The most notable example of this was wood, with Supergirl having to pull a piece out of Power Girl’s back in one comic.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/power-girl-marvel-villains-win-lose/\">5 Marvel Villains Power Girl Would Defeat (&#38; 5 She Would Lose To)</a></span></p>\n                        \n
