                      \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 02:20:31 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/redhood.jpg","linkMd5":"44a455afc4f12d05f3fb89bb0783490d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn4@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-31-083_5d8c5bfaa21c5f0f.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":201434,"destBytes":165192,"author":"Renaldo Matadeen","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/redhood.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn4@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-31-083_5d8c5bfaa21c5f0f.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/red-hood-1-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn46@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-39-971_8a1f4e78d5d1314a.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/2-red-hood-1-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn5@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-55-337_d0d33e47a816d489.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989061},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Marvel: Captain America's 10 Closest Allies | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-captain-america-closest-allies/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Captain-America-Avengers-Feature-Image.jpg\"/></figure><p>There’s no other character like <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/captain%20america/\">Captain America</a> in the Marvel Universe. He’s a character respected by superhero, civilian and government official alike. Part of this is because he’s a straightforward person, but he also stands by his ideals and believes in them no matter what.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Captain America: 15 Steve Rogers Quotes That Inspire All of Us\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/captain-america-steve-rogers-most-inspiring-quotes/\">Captain America: 15 Steve Rogers Quotes That Inspire All of Us</a></span></p><p>Unlike many other heroes in the Marvel Universe, there’s no shortage of allies <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/captain-america-versions-first-avenger-love-see-on-screen/\">Steve Rogers</a> can call on. But which of them has he worked with the most? Which of them has he faced and beaten the biggest threats with? Here we’re looking at not only all of Steve’s closest superhero friends, but those he worked with during the war as well.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>WASP</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Janet-Van-Dyne.jpg' /></figure><p>Janet Van Dyne is a co-founding member of the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/avengers/\">Avengers</a>, which actually means she was part of the team before Steve was, though this is only briefly true.</p><p>After Cap’s incarnation of the Avengers, Wasp would re-join the team and become the leader of the Avengers for some time. Wasp even nominated herself as the leader of the team, and Steve supported her alongside Tony and Thor.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>NAMOR</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Namor.jpg' /></figure><p>It’s hard to say Namor has many allies at all. The <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/namor-good-x-men-worst/\">arrogant ruler of Atlantis</a> is a prickly sort who doesn’t seem to make friends very well. But Captain America is probably one of the closest people that could claim such a thing.</p><p>His time on the Invaders alongside the Captain is a source of nostalgia for the hero, representing an easier time before humanity was wreaking havoc on his oceans and his enemies were more obvious. Though this hasn’t stopped them from going against one another before, Steve Rogers is probably the only member of the Avengers that can get Namor to listen to reason.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>CAPTAIN MARVEL</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Reputation-Captain-Marvel.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mcu-carol-danvers-comic-accurate/\">Carol</a> and Steve have found themselves on opposite sides of major problems within the superhero community more than once, but that doesn’t mean either of them have lost even a shred of respect for one another.</p><p>The two of them have served on multiple <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/beast-belong-avengers-x-men/\">Avengers</a> teams together, and have no problem allowing one another to be the leader based on specific scenarios and situations. Most recently, Captain America even trusted Carol enough to surrender to her when she recently needed to collect all the Avengers for the Kree Supreme Intelligence to avoid bombs going off across the Earth.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>NATASHA ROMANOV</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Black-Widow-2019-Costume.jpeg' /></figure><p>Natasha and Steve met ages ago, during the War where she’d been kidnapped by the Hand. Steve helped save her, though she still wound up immersed in the KGB lifestyle. She worked alongside Bucky as an agent for them, but eventually defected to America.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Get This Man A Shield: 10 Of The Best Captain America Fan Art Pieces On The Internet\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-captain-america-fan-art-best/\">Get This Man A Shield: 10 Of The Best Captain America Fan Art Pieces On The Internet</a></span></p><p>These days, Natasha has been an Avenger as well as operating as a secret agent in the background. She’s even led the team, though people try not to talk about that era, Steve still respects the work she put in at the time.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>DIAMONDBACK</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Captain-America-Diamondback.jpg' /></figure><p>Diamondback was originally a villain working for the Serpent Society, but after a run-in with Steve she very quickly fell in love with him. Despite supposedly being a villain, she wound up switching sides for him.</p><p>Since then she’s become a member of the Avengers Resistance, helping to take down H.A.M.M.E.R. Lately she spends more of her time running with Domino and her group, but she’s still more than proven her willingness to help Cap in any situation.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>THOR</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Thor.jpg' /></figure><p>Thor has the utmost respect for Steve, as someone who charges into battle with far less strength and power than most of the other <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/original-uncanny-avengers-lineup-ranked/\">Avengers</a> and the people he fights alongside.</p><p>But Steve has proven himself a capable leader time and time again as an Avenger, and Thor has gladly followed him into battle.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>IRON MAN</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Iron-Man-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>Perhaps someone Steve has the most contentious relationship with. Steve and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-iron-man-love-interests-ranked-best/\">Tony</a> are two heroes that have worked with one another the most while also being two heroes that have come to blows the most as well.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"MCU: 10 Captain America Memes Only True Fans Will Laugh At\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/captain-america-mcu-memes-funny/\">MCU: 10 Captain America Memes Only True Fans Will Laugh At</a></span></p><p>Dating back to the 80s these two have had issues with one another. However, during the last Civil War, Tony immediately took Cap’s side because he knows who’s generally going to be on the right side of things.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>BUCKY BARNES</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Winter-Soldier.jpg' /></figure><p>The oldest friend Steve has, Bucky Barnes was originally one of the people he fought alongside during the war. The two of them managed to become allies again in the present day after freeing Bucky’s mind from being controlled, and now they work together on multiple missions against Hydra and most of Captain America’s biggest foes.</p><p>Bucky even took over Steve’s place briefly in the late 2000s. These days, Bucky helps Steve from the shadows thanks to people knowing who he is.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>FALCON</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Falcon-Captain-America-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>It’s impossible to talk about <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/reasons-ultimate-captain-america-is-better-original/\">Captain America</a> without also talking about Sam Wilson. While Bucky might be the ally he’s known the longest, Sam Wilson is the person Cap’s worked with the most. Their stories date back to the 70’s, with him being invited to join the Avengers only a decade after his introduction.</p><p>When Captain America needed to choose a replacement, Sam was the man he chose, and he held the shield and identity for several years until Steve could take the job once more. There’s probably no other man in the world Steve trusts more.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>SHARON CARTER</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Sharon-Carter.jpg' /></figure><p>Sharon and Steve first met while Sharon was on a mission, with Steve saving her from an encounter with Batroc the Leaper. Since then, the two have worked together on countless missions. And as these things happen, they eventually fell in love and wound up dating one another.</p><p>After their time in Dimension Z, Sharon’s a bit older than she was back in the day, but the two of them are no less passionate for one another.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"5 Reasons We Prefer Captain America's Original Shield (&#38; 5 Why His Modern One Is The Right Choice)\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/captain-america-shield-modern-vs-original/\">5 Reasons We Prefer Captain America's Original Shield (&#38; 5 Why His Modern One Is The Right Choice)</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 22:00:15 Ashford","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Captain-America-Avengers-Feature-Image.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn78@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-29-155_19ef4a3c31252504.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Janet-Van-Dyne.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn92@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-35-392_a549d54c34d7abe2.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Namor.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn28@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-40-330_bd8d41ca2273485b.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Reputation-Captain-Marvel.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn14@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-38-730_99c11cb9118a22b3.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Black-Widow-2019-Costume.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn34@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-36-764_36cae53f4f38d210.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Captain-America-Diamondback.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn21@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-43-428_05bb37ea6f1ac82b.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Thor.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn91@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-37-089_0b13d1e12eec3a37.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Iron-Man-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn85@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-43-133_7db03473422aa931.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Winter-Soldier.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn82@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-43-236_890bd4af84019771.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Falcon-Captain-America-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn58@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-42-036_b72c4b3685ac9c16.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/Sharon-Carter.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn31@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-39-734_453f705554eeca45.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989069},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Is One Piece Hiding a GRIM Secret About Devil Fruits? | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/one-piece-grim-secret-about-devil-fruits/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/luffy-devil-fruit.jpg\"/></figure><p>Early on, <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/one-piece\"><em>One Piece's</em></a> Eiichiro Oda established very clear rules about how the Devil Fruits work. Anyone who eats a one will gain extraordinary powers that could alter their body, cause an animal transformation or <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/one-piece-water-7-arc-sets-up-perfect-pay-off/\">ruin their life entirely</a>. However, this power comes at a cost as they will lose their ability to swim, become weak if they touch kairoseki stone, and if a Devil Fruit user eats a second one, they will die. Oh, and the fruits also taste super bad. But the incredible thing about these rules is how they're malleable enough to allow aberrations without breaking entirely.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Crunchyroll Expo Adds Junji Ito, One Piece, The Rising of the Shield Hero Panels To Line-Up\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/crunchyroll-expo-junji-ito-one-piece-the-rising-of-the-shield-hero/\">Crunchyroll Expo Adds Junji Ito, One Piece, The Rising Of The Shield Hero Panels To Line-Up</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/One-Piece-Devil-Fruits.jpg\"/></figure><p>After <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/whitebeard-why-one-piece-strongest-man-die/\">Whitebeard's last stand against Blackbeard </a>and his newly formed crew of Impel Down prisoners, the man considered the strongest in the world took his final breath. Taking advantage of the situation, the vile pirates put a sheet over Whitebeard as Teach Blackbeard walked under it. When he came out from under it, he possessed power of Whitebeard's Devil Fruit, the Quake-Quake Fruit. With it came the ability to create tremors, in addition to Blackbeard's own power to control darkness from the Dark-Dark Fruit. Teach became the first person to ever possess two Devil Fruit abilities, and though it's still unclear how he was able to take Whitebeard's power or even be able to possess two without dying, there's one solid theory that comes <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/one-piece-episode-937-rebellion-against-kaido/\">from another Yonko</a>.</p><p>When a Devil Fruit user dies, the fruit they obtained their power from regrows somewhere else in the world. There can never exist more than one Devil Fruit with the same power nor the same user. However, decades prior, Charlotte Linlin, better known as <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/one-piece-key-events-vol-94/\">the Yonko, Big Mom</a>, got her own Devil Fruit ability in a similarly unusual way. It all began where she grew up: on Elbaf, home of the Giant race, in an orphanage run by the nun Mother Caramel.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Franky X Robin?: All the Hints That the One Piece Nakama Belong Together\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/one-piece-franky-robin-nakama-hints-belong-together/\">Franky X Robin?: All The Hints That The One Piece Nakama Belong Together</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/big-mom-as-kid-one-piece-yonko.jpg\"/></figure><p>In chapter 867, after an incident that forced them to leave Elbaf, the orphanage celebrated Linlin's 6th birthday with a delightful tea party. Linlin unknowingly devoured everything and, when she finished eating, her surroundings were empty and her family was nowhere in sight, but she now possessed Mother Caramel's Soul-Soul Fruit powers, giving her the ability to manipulate the souls of living beings. It's a horrifically morbid truth to behold, but Linlin must have devoured her entire family without realizing, which is how she obtained her adoptive mother's powers. With that being the case, it seems that a person can obtain a Devil Fruit user's power by eating them or a part them, so it could mean Blackbeard stole the Quake-Quake Fruit's power by eating part of Whitebeard or at least one of his organs.</p><p>This is only one possible theory on how one pirate acquired the other's abilities, but the fact that such an event is still theorized to this day speaks volumes about how much is still unknown about the workings of the Devil Fruits. Who knows how Oda will surprise us in the future.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"One Piece: The Storytelling GENIUS of the Manga's Cover Stories\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/one-piece-oda-storytelling-genius-of-mangas-cover-stories/\">One Piece: The Storytelling GENIUS Of The Manga's Cover Stories</a></span></p>\n                        \n Russo","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/luffy-devil-fruit.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn32@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-30-411_ba8cc6caa485ce85.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/One-Piece-Devil-Fruits.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn68@2020_1/2020/09/05/06-56-36-316_fc1e07f8c023ec78.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/big-mom-as-kid-one-piece-yonko.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn24@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-35-822_d613275429d8140f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989072},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Amazon's Jack Reacher Series Casts Titans Star Alan Ritchson in Lead Role","link":"https://www.cbr.com/amazon-jack-reacher-alan-ritchson/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/jack-reacher-hawk-2-header.jpg\"/></figure><p>Amazon Studios, Skydance TV and Paramount TV's <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/jack-reacher-tv/\">Jack Reacher</a></em> series has cast <em>Titans</em> star Alan Ritchson in the lead role.</p><p>Developed by Nick Santora, Amazon <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/jack-reacher-series-in-development-amazon/\">acquired the license</a> to Lee Child's <em>Jack Reach</em><em>er</em> novel series in July 2019. Santora will serve as the first season's head writer, executive producer and showrunner, and it will adapt the first Jack Reacher novel, <em>The Killing Floor</em>, with Child himself also serving as an executive producer.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Everything Coming to Amazon Prime Video September 2020\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/everything-coming-to-amazon-prime-video-september-2020/\">Everything Coming To Amazon Prime Video September 2020</a></span></p><p>Child's <em>Jack Reacher</em> series -- which includes several novels, novellas and short stories -- has sold over 100 million copies worldwide to date. A <em>Jack Reacher </em>film adaptation was released by Skydance Productions and Paramount Pictures in 2012, and a sequel, titled <em>Jack Reacher: Never Go Back</em>, was released four years late. Both films starred actor Tom Cruise as the titular ex-Army Military Police Corps officer.</p><p>Notably, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dwayne-johnson-grateful-for-not-getting-jack-reacher-role/\">Dwayne \"The Rock\" Johnson once saw himself</a> in the role of Jack Reacher -- at least for the film adaptation -- though the actor has since admitted he's grateful he didn't get the part.</p><p>Starring Alan Ritchson, <em>Jack Reacher</em> is executive produced by Nick Santora, Lee Child, Don Granger, Scott Sullivan, Christopher McQuarrie, David Ellison, Dana Goldberg and Marcy Ross. The series has yet to receive a premiere date.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Highfire: Nicolas Cage to Voice Vodka-Drinking, Dancing Dragon in Amazon Series\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/highfire-nicolas-cage-drinking-dancing-dragon-amazon-series/\">Highfire: Nicolas Cage To Voice Vodka-Drinking, Dancing Dragon In Amazon Series</a></span></p><p>(via <em><a href=\"https://deadline.com/2020/09/alan-ritchson-cast-jack-reacher-title-character-star-amazon-tv-series-lee-child-adaptation-1234570323/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Deadline</a></em>)</p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 19:50:37 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/jack-reacher-hawk-2-header.jpg","linkMd5":"ae7ac88f76416cc48a33c9c95b72fb99","destWidth":1200,"destHeight":600,"sourceBytes":148466,"destBytes":148466,"author":"Jon Arvedon","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/jack-reacher-hawk-2-header.jpg":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989072},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"REVIEW: Marvel's Avengers is a Perfectly Serviceable Beat 'Em Up...For Now","link":"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-avengers-perfectly-serviceable-review/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Marvels-Avengers-Heros-Key-Art-Golden-Gate.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><strong>WARNING: The following contains spoilers for </strong></em><strong><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/marvels-avengers\">Marvel's Avengers</a></strong><em><strong>, available now.</strong></em></p><p>There came a game, a game unlike any other! Earth's Mightiest Heroes are at long last reuniting in Square Enix and Crystal Dynamics' <em>Marvel's Avengers</em>. This powerhouse beat 'em up is poised to celebrate the monumental <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/avengers\">Avengers</a> franchise, as well as the transition between console generations.</p><p>It's weird that it took this long to get a new Avengers game. Sure, there was a Kinect game that nobody remembers, and you could make a case for <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/marvel-ultimate-alliance-3-the-black-order\">Ultimate Alliance</a></em>, but the last \"real\" Avengers game was 1995's forgettable <em>Avengers in Galactic Storm</em>. Square Enix and Crystal Dynamics set out to make the long-overdue video game celebration of the Avengers, and they pulled it off...mostly.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/ps4-avengers-destroys-team-and-it-works\">Marvel's Avengers SHATTERS the Team Like NEVER Before - That's Why It Works</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Marvels-Avengers-game-team.jpg\"/></figure><p>Following a Terrigen explosion and the death of <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/captain-america\">Captain America</a>, the Avengers are outlawed and the world sees the newly created <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/inhumans\">Inhumans</a> as threats. Five years later, former Avengers scientist George Tarleton has created A.I.M. and is hunting both the Inhumans and an Inhuman Resistance. Meanwhile, Inhuman Kamala Khan is being hunted after finding proof Tarleton may have been responsible for Captain America's death.</p><p>The story mode is where <em>Marvel's Avengers</em> shines, but it's not perfect. There are a few twists and turns, but they're all pretty obvious if you're a comic book fan. Characterization saves the game, but not all the characters are perfect; Tony Stark is a little less rock star superhero and a little more \"your dad is going to save the day,\" for example. Still, the game finds plenty of time to reinvent; the Avengers are interesting, and these may be the best versions of A.I.M. and M.O.D.O.K. we've seen to date.</p><p>The problem is that a lot of characterization is missing. Characters who were hyped up in early marketing, such as <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvels-avengers-crystal-dynamics-interview/\">Cerise, an Inhuman who uses a wheelchair,</a> or Maria Hill, don't contribute much to the plot or gameplay. Storied Avengers don't acknowledge each other's existence. Characters who hated each other appear to reconcile immediately. The important beats of reconnecting feel like they're missing from a story that's all about getting the band back together. The story exists only to justify who is going to fight and why.</p><p>What story it does have is good, at least. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvels-avengers-bruce-kamala-relationship-defines-game/\">Kamala and Bruce</a> remain the highlight; their contrasting personalities perfectly embody <em>Avengers</em>' tone. The characters are exciting when the plot needs them to be, and emotional beats still hit hard. You'll find yourself incredibly attached to the infectiously positive Kamala by the story's end, so much so that even her final moments before the credits can bring tears to your eyes.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvels-avengers-playstations-most-downloaded-beta/\">Marvel's Avengers is PlayStation's Most-Downloaded Beta Ever</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Marvel-Avengers-video-game-2.jpg\"/></figure><p>The story's fine, but it's all just there to justify the gameplay. <em>Marvel's Avengers</em> simultaneously has gameplay in spades while also not having much. At its core, <em>Avengers</em> is closer to a looter shooter like <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/borderlands/\">Borderlands</a></em> or <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/destiny-2\">Destiny 2</a></em> than a superhero game like <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/spider-man-ps4\">Marvel's Spider-Man</a></em> or the <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/batman-arkham\">Batman: Arkham</a></em> titles.</p><p>Missions begin from a War Table and are accompanied by brief flavor text. From there, you're dropped into the fray. Missions have you facing off against various A.I.M. baddies, even when it doesn't seem like you should be. Combat is fast and action-packed, but not always fun. The difficulty curve tends to consist of an enemy you can handle alone surrounded by smaller, additional enemies. The result is a chaotic, overwhelming mess that's at best difficult to manage and, at worst, an impossible onslaught that leaves you stunlocked.</p><p>In these instances, the game thinks you'll be OK <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvels-avengers-companion-ai-keep-gamers-playing-hours/\">thanks to your A.I. controlled companions</a>, but it would be wrong. We lost several fights because our A.I. companions had wandered off and in one case, appeared to despawn. One encounter saw <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/thor\">Thor</a> and <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/hulk\">Hulk</a> staring at a wall around the corner; since they didn't have a direct sightline, they were seemingly oblivious to the robot stepping on <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/iron-man\">Iron Man</a> not five feet away. Games like <em>Ultimate Alliance</em> solve this by allowing you some degree of control or influence, but here you cannot summon, control or even get the attention of your A.I. teammates.</p><p>The fights don't appear to be designed with every Avenger in mind, either. Every character has options for ranged and close encounters, but they aren't all well suited for it. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvels-avengers-gameplay-footage-captain-america-skills-costumes/\">Captain America</a> is the most fun character in the game, but he struggles against air units or hovering warships. The A.I. should be supporting you in these instances, but again ours often would break and watch as Cap frantically threw his shield a hundred times over at the one remaining weak point on a ship.</p><p>These are significant issues when they pop up, but fortunately, they're not often, at least not until the end of the story mode. The missions remain varied enough to keep them interesting, and the Avengers do play differently enough that you don't find it feeling stale. It's worth remembering that the game is built for the long haul, and gameplay may be significantly improved just by the upcoming roster expansions, which will likely add additional play styles.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvels-avengers-hawkeye-kate-bishop-roster-reveal/\">Marvel's Avengers: The MCU's Next Disney+ Star, Kate Bishop, Joins The Roster</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Marvels-Avengers-A-Day-team.jpg\"/></figure><p>The <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvels-avengers-beta-gorgeous-far-from-perfect/\"><em>Avengers</em> Beta was gorgeous</a>, and the main game is no exception. The character models are well-rendered, and the animation is fluid and exciting. Traversing the world is an adventure, and there's plenty to see and do. But the game needed a lot more polish, especially in the back half.</p><p>Around two-thirds through story mode, graphical issues began popping up. Screen tearing, visual artifacts and even small issues like character mouths not moving or models getting stuck were prevalent. At one point, we found a floating Iron Man head on the Helicarrier at a point in the story when he was explicitly not on the Helicarrier. Later on, a S.H.I.E.L.D. agent may have secretly been a Mr. Fantastic cameo, based on how his neck was stretching to the sky from underneath the floor.</p><p>While those are temporary issues that can usually be blamed on a bad load, they don't excuse the frame rate or lack thereof. Multiple instances in the game saw stuttering, slowdown and a frame rate that dropped to single digits. Some cutscenes would stutter to the point that characters seemed to teleport to their marks. The game has a lot of trouble when large numbers of enemies are on screen at once, a trick it relies on in later missions. The game is a gorgeous, graphical powerhouse when it's working, but these visual problems occasionally ruined the mood.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvels-avengers-co-op-wont-cross-platform-launch/\">Marvel's Avengers Co-Op Won't Be Cross-Platform At Launch</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Continuity-Avengers-Game.jpg\"/></figure><p><em>Marvel's Avengers</em> is perfectly serviceable. That's really all you can say about it for now. It's an ambitious title, and one that's coming out at a weird time in gaming, caught between building for a dying generation and preparing for the next stage of hardware. With a rumored 10-year life cycle, a host of DLC and the on-going Avengers Initiative component, the game is far from being done. <em>Marvel's Avengers</em> has all the hallmarks of a game that will go from just OK to incredible after a couple of years of DLC and quality of life patches.</p><p>For now, though, the game is fine. For the casual fan who doesn't have a strong attachment outside the <a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/marvel-cinematic-universe\">MCU</a> or is looking for a new beat 'em up, this probably isn't the game for them. This game is driven by a love for the characters and is aimed at die-hard fans. <em>Marvel's Avengers</em> is rough around the edges, but it's a decent celebration of what makes the Avengers so compelling.</p><p>Developed by Crystal Dynamics and Eidos-Montréal and published by Square Enix, <em>Marvel's Avengers</em> is now available on PlayStation 4, Xbox One, Google Stadia and PC.</p><p><em>A copy of Marvel's Avengers was provided by Square Enix to CBR for review purposes.</em></p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvels-avengers-first-look-modok-monica-rappaccini/\">Marvel's Avengers Debuts First Look at MODOK, Monica Rappaccini</a></span></p>\n                        \n His powers grant him heat vision, super strength and near invulnerability. So we’ve never really gotten into the 'How do you stop him physically?' But there are a lot of ways to stop him psychologically.\"</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-boys-season-2-billy-joel-blessing/\">The Boys Season 2 Gets Billy Joel's Blessing</a></span></p><p>Kripke further elaborated on this weakness, saying that Homelander's self-loathing could ultimately do him in. \"He finds his human vulnerability so hateful and he hates that part of him and he tries to subsume it, and yet it is part of who he is,\" he said. Homelander's psychosis was well documented in Season 1, particularly through his maternal fixation with deceased Vought CEO Madelyn Stillwell (Elisabeth Shue).</p><p>Streaming now on Amazon Prime Video<em>, The Boys</em> stars Karl Urban as Billy Butcher, Jack Quaid as Hughie, Laz Alonso as Mother's Milk, Tomer Kapon as Frenchie, Karen Fukuhara as the Female, Erin Moriarty as Annie January, Chace Crawford as the Deep, Antony Starr as Homelander, Aya Cash as Stormfront and Simon Pegg as Hughie's dad. engaging with third party platforms.</p><p>According to <a href=\"https://www.wrestlinginc.com/news/2020/09/exclusive-vince-mcmahon-threatens-to-punish-talent-engaging-674408/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Wrestling Inc.</a>, WWE held a call with its talent last Sunday regarding the future of its on-screen product, during which the company informed the wrestlers that it not only owns their ring names, but also their real names. This call was followed up on Thursday by a letter from WWE Chairman and CEO Vince McMahon himself, who told the performers that they have 30 days to stop engaging with third parties, which <em>Wrestling Inc.</em> speculates includes platforms like Twitch and Cameo.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/wwe-releases-aops-akam-and-rezar/\">WWE Releases AOP's Akam and Rezar</a></span></p><p>\"Some of you are engaged with outside third parties using your name and likeness in ways that are detrimental to our company,\" the alleged letter from Vinny Mac reads. \"It is imperative that these activities be terminated within the next 30 days (by Friday October 2). on a cliffhanger full of dread for our main characters. Bourne. The series airs on Wednesdays at 8 p.m. ET/PT on The CW.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/100-sheidheda-tightens-rule-kills-children-gabriel/\">The 100: Sheidheda Tightens His Rule and Kills [SPOILER]</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 18:17:03 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/100-final-season.jpg","linkMd5":"1c296275c06f239aeeac00448b035c18","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn96@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-30-398_860b352b41ac0556.webp","destWidth":1200,"destHeight":600,"sourceBytes":141046,"destBytes":105774,"author":"Sam Stone","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/100-final-season.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn96@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-30-398_860b352b41ac0556.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989074},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"REPORT: WWE Is Considering Moving NXT Off of Wednesday Nights","link":"https://www.cbr.com/wwe-reportedly-moving-nxt-to-tuesdays/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/NXT-AEW-e1599163628276.jpeg\"/></figure><p><em>NXT</em>'s move away from a Wednesday night showdown with AEW could reportedly become permanent.</p><p>According to the @WrestleVotes Twitter account, which has been known to break <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/wwe/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">WWE</a>-related news in the past, discussions on whether to move the weekly show of the company's third brand have been going on for about a month now. The tweet also noted that, while talks remain on-going behind the scenes, \"<span class=\"css-901oao css-16my406 r-1qd0xha r-ad9z0x r-bcqeeo r-qvutc0\">The numbers over the next 2 weeks might have some impact on this decision.</span>\"</p><iframe width=\"320\" height=\"320\" frameborder=\"0\" src=\"https://twitter.com/WrestleVotes/status/1301212403380690944?s=20\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/aew-chris-jericho-hyping-ratings-war-stop/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">AEW: Chris Jericho Keeps Hyping a Ratings War With NXT - and NEEDS to Stop</a></span></p><p>Dubbing them \"Super Tuesdays,\" WWE has moved the Sept. 1 and 8 episodes of <em>NXT</em> up a day from its usual Wednesday night time slot, but is expected to revert back to normal after that.</p><p>This past week, NXT pulled in 849,000 viewers for a Tuesday show headlined by a Fatal Four-Way between Tommaso Ciampa, Adam Cole, Johnny Gargano and Finn Balor for the vacant <em>NXT</em> Championship. That number represents an increase of approximately 25,000 over its viewership six days earlier. The show also saw its highest ratings of the year in the 18-49 demographic.</p><p>NXT's current move to Tuesday nights comes on the heels of months of AEW<em> Dynamite</em> outperforming the weekly program in the 9:00-11:00pm (EST) slot, with <em>Dynamite</em> handily winning the 18-49 demo most weeks. However, the Aug. 19 episode saw <em>NXT</em> earn a considerable victory with its highest viewing audience of the year to date.</p><p>Switching to Tuesday night would not make <em>NXT</em> the only professional wrestling programming on TV. <em>Impact Wrestling</em> airs every Tuesday night on AXS TV, but only pulls in roughly 150,000 viewers per week, making it a considerably less daunting rival than AEW.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/when-will-wwe-start-poaching-aew-talent/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">When Will WWE Start Poaching AEW Talent?</a></span></p><p>For its part, AEW also reaped the benefits of an unrivaled time slot, drawing 928,000 viewers for the go-home edition of <em>Dynamite</em> prior to Saturday's <em>All Out</em> pay-per-view to garner the TNT program's best ratings in months.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">The two shows will run on alternate dates again next week, with <em>NXT</em> featuring a championship battle between Cole and Balor.</span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 17:37:36 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/NXT-AEW-e1599163628276.jpeg","linkMd5":"37c5b59008e9d3c2bc8d2b3baeab18fc","destWidth":1920,"destHeight":960,"sourceBytes":162430,"destBytes":162430,"author":"Ben Fisher","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/NXT-AEW-e1599163628276.jpeg":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989076},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"The Expanse Gets Four-Issue Miniseries From BOOM! Studios | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/expanse-boom-studios-miniseries/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/boom-expanse-header.jpg\"/></figure><p><a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/boom-studios\">BOOM! Studios</a> has announced that Amazon Prime Video's <em><a href=\"http://cbr.com/tag/the-expanse\">The Expanse</a></em> is getting a four-issue miniseries from Corinna Bechko and Alejandro Aragon.</p><p>BOOM! Studios' official press release is below:</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Kurt Vonnegut’s Slaughterhouse-Five Comes to Life in BOOM! Studios Graphic Novel Preview\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/kurt-vonnegut-slaughterhouse-five-boom-studios-preview/\">Kurt Vonnegut’s Slaughterhouse-Five Comes To Life In BOOM! Studios Graphic Novel Preview</a></span></p><p><em><strong>LOS ANGELES, CA (September 4, 2020)</strong><span style=\"font-family: arial, 'helvetica neue', helvetica, sans-serif;\"> – BOOM! Studios is proud to announce <strong>THE EXPANSE</strong>, a new four-issue limited comic book series from writer Corinna Bechko (Green Lantern: Earth One) and artist Alejandro Aragon (Resonant) which is set between Season 4 and the upcoming fifth season of the Amazon Prime Video hit television series, The Expanse. The limited comic book series is available in comic shops starting December 2, 2020.</span></em></p><p><em>The first four seasons of The Expanse television show are available to watch now on Prime Video. The show is financed and produced by Alcon Television Group, a division of Alcon Entertainment.</em></p><p><em><strong>THE EXPANSE </strong>picks up with Chrisjen Avasarala at the end of the television show’s fourth season. The longtime Secretary-General of the United Nations finds herself dealing with the outcome of the tumultuous elections for her position and far from Earth but not its politics. When Bobbie Draper - a former Martian marine - brings Avasarala intel on an intergalactic black market weapons ring, Avasarala sees a chance to reclaim her political position through a clandestine operation. But as Draper digs deeper into this secret cabal, she soon realizes the threat they pose is far larger - and closer to home - than either of them ever imagined.</em></p><p><em>Corinna Bechko has been writing both comics and prose since her horror graphic novel Heathentown was published by Image/Shadowline in 2009. She has worked for numerous publishers including Marvel, DC, Dark Horse, BOOM! Studios, and Sideshow on titles such as Star Wars: Legacy, Savage Hulk, Angel, Once Upon a Time, Court of the Dead: The Chronicle of the Underworld and the Hugo-nominated series Invisible Republic, which she co-writes with Gabriel Hardman. Green Lantern: Earth One, co-written with Gabriel Hardman, was nominated for an Eisner in 2019. Her book for young readers, Smithsonian Dig it! Dinosaurs, co-written with Brenda Scott Royce, appeared last year as well. She lives in Los Angeles and has a zoology degree, both of which probably influence her writing even more than she realizes.</em></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/boom-expanse-1.jpg\"/></figure><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/boom-expanse-2.jpg\"/></figure><p><em>\"I couldn't be more excited to add a piece to the universe of <strong>THE EXPANSE</strong>!” said Bechko. \"It's a show I both adore and admire, so the chance to craft a noir-tinged plot involving two of my absolute favorite characters from the series makes me feel like the luckiest writer around.\"</em></p><p><em>Alejandro Aragon is a comic book artist from Rosario, Argentina. Aragon's illustrations have been published by BOOM! Studios, Image Comics, Dark Horse, IDW, Vault Comics, and more. He is also the co-creator of comic book series Resonant with Vault Comics and Death Orb with Dark Horse.</em></p><p><em>\"<strong>THE EXPANSE </strong>is one of the best sci-fi television shows out there right now. I am honored to be a part of this journey and very excited to draw this universe and the incredible characters in it,\" said Aragon.</em></p><p><em>\"Corinna and Alejandro are the perfect team to tackle the complicated relationship between two of the most compelling and unpredictable characters in The Expanse,\" said Eric Harburn, Senior Editor, BOOM! Studios. \"Fans of epic science-fiction, political intrigue, and the machinations of Martians, Earthers, and Belters can’t miss a single moment of this tie-in series that sets the stage for the newest season of the beloved television series.\"</em></p><p><em><strong>THE EXPANSE</strong> is the latest release from BOOM! Studios’ eponymous imprint, home to critically acclaimed original series, including Once &#38; Future by Kieron Gillen and Dan Mora; Something is Killing the Children by James Tynion IV and Werther Dell’Edera; Faithless by Brian Azzarello and Maria Llovet; The Red Mother by Jeremy Haun and Danny Luckert; Alienated by Simon Spurrier and Chris Wildgoose; King of Nowhere by W. Maxwell Prince and Tyler Jenkins; Wynd by James Tynion IV and Michael Dialynas; Seven Secrets by Tom Taylor and Daniele Di Nicuolo; and We Only Find Them When They’re Dead by Al Ewing and Simone Di Meo. The imprint also publishes popular licensed properties including Joss Whedon’s Firefly from Greg Pak and Dan McDaid; Buffy the Vampire Slayer from Jordie Bellaire and David López; Angel from Bryan Edward Hill and Gleb Melnikov; and Mighty Morphin Power Rangers from Ryan Parrott and Daniele Di Nicuolo.</em></p><p><em><span style=\"font-family: arial, 'helvetica neue', helvetica, sans-serif;\">Print copies of <strong>THE EXPANSE #1</strong>, featuring main cover art by artist W. Scott Forbes (Firefly), as well as variant cover art by Tigh Walker (Venom: Annual) and more, will be available December 2, 2020 exclusively at local comic book shops (use <a href=\"http://comicshoplocator.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">comicshoplocator.com</a> to find the one nearest you) or at the BOOM! Studios webstore. Digital copies can be purchased from content providers like comiXology, iBooks, Google Play, and Madefire. </span></em></p><p><em><span style=\"font-family: arial, 'helvetica neue', helvetica, sans-serif;\">For continuing news on <strong>THE EXPANSE</strong> comic book series and more from BOOM! Studios, stay tuned to <a href=\"http://%20www.boom-studios.com/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">www.boom-studios.com</a> and follow <a href=\"https://twitter.com/boomstudios\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">@boomstudios</a> on Twitter.</span></em></p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Universal Content Productions Taps Grant Morrison to Launch Comics Division\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/universal-content-productions-grant-morrison-comics-division/\">Universal Content Productions Taps Grant Morrison To Launch Comics Division</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 18:05:11 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/boom-expanse-header.jpg","linkMd5":"d04f0c83da7cdeb2ad52f2d707af32ff","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn37@2020_1/2020/09/05/06-56-31-347_5dc46a02b60b5397.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":47138,"destBytes":43736,"author":"Jon Arvedon","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/boom-expanse-header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn37@2020_1/2020/09/05/06-56-31-347_5dc46a02b60b5397.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/boom-expanse-1.jpg":null,"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/boom-expanse-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn84@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-43-927_fae1bfccc1bd78d2.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989075},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"DC Comics: 10 Heroes You Didn’t Know Started At A Different Publisher","link":"https://www.cbr.com/dc-heroes-from-different-publishers/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/blackhawk-and-the-ray.jpg\"/></figure><p>Over the years, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/dc-comics/\">DC Comics</a> has incorporated other companies' characters and heroes into their publishing. In 1953, DC Comics purchased Quality Comics and integrated many of their heroes. In the 1970s, they acquired Fawcett, home of the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/shazam/\">Shazam</a> family of characters. Just before <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/crisis-on-infinite-earths/\"><em>Crisis on Infinite Earths</em></a>, they acquired <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/charlton-comics/\">Charlton Comics</a>' roster of super-heroes.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/comic-stories-shazam-2-never-done-live-action/\">10 Comic Stories We Want To See In Shazam! 2 (That Have Never Been Done In Live-Action)</a></span></p><p>The incorporation of other companies' heroes didn't stop. Most recently, they merged the Wildstorm Universe into the New 52. While the Wildstorm heroes have not been able to break through and maintain a title, many of these acquisitions have become ingrained into the DC zeitgeist. Some characters <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-shazam-comics-fun-facts-trivia/\">like Shazam</a> are even well-known to be originally from another publisher.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>Kid Eternity</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/kid-eternity.jpg' /></figure><p>Kid Eternity was published by Quality Comics, not the Marvel Family's Fawcett Comics. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/grant-morrison/\">Grant Morrison</a> revamped the character for <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/vertigo\">Vertigo</a>. His Golden Age past is elaborated on in a revision that makes him a pawn of the Lords of Chaos. He's been used in the pages of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/teen-titans/\"><em>Teen Titans</em></a> and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/jsa/\"><em>JSA</em></a> and has even been killed a couple of times.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Peacemaker</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/peacemaker.jpg' /></figure><p>The Peacemaker is going to appear in James Gunn's <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/suicide-squad/\">Suicide Squad</a></em> film. He'll be portrayed by John Cena, so many fans will get the misconception that he's always been a DC Character. He's one of those characters that started at Charlton Comics.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/watchmen-aged-well-hasnt/\">5 Ways Watchmen Has Aged Well (&#38; 5 Ways It Hasn't)</a></span></p><p>The tag line immortally bound with the character is that he's \"A man who loves peace so much that he's willing to fight for it!\" This would later change to \"kill for it.\" While originally using non-lethal means, this quickly changed, especially during his time at DC Comics. He was also the basis for the Comedian in <em>Watchmen</em>.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Sarge Steel</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/sarge-steel.jpg' /></figure><p>There's something about Sarge Steel that became almost iconic with his artificial hand. Initially a Charlton Comics character, his hand was lost to drug lords, and Sarge Steel had it replaced with a metal fist with which he could club enemies. He was a Vietnam veteran working as a private eye. Later, he was made a Special Agent. This role was made integral to his adaption by DC Comics.</p><p>DC Comics made him the head of a federal agency and later a cabinet post over metahumans like the Suicide Squad. He's been used as a pawn against super-heroes by Circe, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/shazam-captain-marvel-mister-mind-monster-society-brigade/\">Mister Mind</a>, and Doctor Psycho. He remains a fixture of DC's Intelligence and spy operations.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Son of Vulcan</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/son-of-vulcan.jpg' /></figure><p>Son of Vulcan is another of those heroes that DC tried to do something with, but couldn't quite make it happen. A lot of that comes from an origin dependent upon the Greek Gods being active in the affairs of men. Of course, this is the domain of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/wonder-woman/\">Wonder Woman</a> and Shazam in the world of DC Comics.</p><p>Coming from Charlton Comics, Son of Vulcan was not a major Charlton character. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/marv-wolfman\">Marv Wolfman</a> didn't include him among the Earth-4 heroes assembled in <em>Crisis on Infinite Earths #6</em>. He only received a cameo in one panel of the final issue. Afterward, the character had a role in the <em>War of the Gods</em>. He was revamped in 2005 with ties to the White Martians and Teen Titans.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Blue Beetle</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Ted-Kord.jpg' /></figure><p>Ted Kord was the Blue Beetle that heralded the Charlton characters' integration into DC Comics' roster of heroes in <em>Crisis on Infinite Earths #1</em>. He was the second Blue Beetle. The character had roots going back before Charlton Comics into the first years of the Golden Age.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-comics-blue-beetle-ted-kord-vs-jamie-reyes-who-would-win-fight/\">Blue Beetle (Ted Kord) Vs. Blue Beetle (Jaime Reyes): Who Would Win</a></span></p><p>Police officer Dan Garrett was the first Blue Beetle, with adventures published by Fox Comics and Holyoke Publishing. Ted Kord's stories retroactively changed him into an archaeologist gaining powers from a scarab he recovered on a dig in Egypt. Ted Kord was a student of Garrett and inherited the mantle of the Blue Beetle, but not the scarab. Ted went on to be a regular fixture in the DC Universe during the 1980s and into the 1990s.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>The Ray</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/the-ray-dc-comics-version.jpg' /></figure><p>The Ray has had a mixed time at DC, never quite rising above team level status. The version most fans are familiar with debuted in 1992 as the son of the Golden Age Ray. That Ray had been known as a member of the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/freedom-fighters/\">Freedom Fighters</a> but goes back a little further.</p><p>The Ray originally debuted in comics published by Quality Comics. Like with most of the Freedom Fighters, his new adventures following the Crisis were extended to a legacy character, his son. That son has had a long run with DC, serving in many teams and appearing in many crossovers.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Uncle Sam</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/uncle-sam.jpg' /></figure><p>Uncle Sam has shown up a few times since being reintroduced to comic book fans. As the leader of the Freedom Fighters, he was regarded among DC's heroes with awe, with many not doubting that he was the living spirit of America.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-comics-freedom-fighters-forgotten-facts-trivia-lore/\">DC: 10 Things Everyone Forgets About The Freedom Fighters</a></span></p><p>Uncle Sam first appeared in <em>National Comics #1</em>, published by Quality Comics. He was created by none other than Will Eisner. DC incorporated many of the characters it bought from Quality Comics into the Freedom Fighters. After the Crisis, the character appeared infrequently, but was featured in a two-issue <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-vertigo-comics-imprint-bands-needed-obsolete/\">Vertigo series</a> by <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/alex-ross/\">Alex Ross</a> and in a series of short <em>Freedom Fighters</em> series introducing new teammates for Uncle Sam.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Max Mercury</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Max-Mercury.jpg' /></figure><p>Max Mercury was forgotten by many fans, but he is a Golden Age speedster. In <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/flash\"><em>Flash</em></a> and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/impulse/\"><em>Impulse</em></a>, he took on a role as a mentor, especially to Impulse. Of course, no one will find the Golden Age adventures of \"Max Mercury\" because he was known as Quicksilver when being published by Quality Comics. He even got a Who's Who entry under that name but was never published by DC under that name.</p><p>Of course, his name was changed when Mark Waid introduced him in the pages of <em>The Flash</em> to avoid confusion with Marvel Comics' Quicksilver. He became a Speed Force <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-comics-flash-barry-allen-closest-allies-superman-iris-west/\">mentor to Wally West</a> and then Bart Allen. He's been influential enough to have a lasting presence as an extended member of the Flash family of speedsters.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Blackhawk</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/blackhawk-american-flag.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/blackhawk/\">The Blackhawks</a> were a team of ace pilots that fought against the Axis powers and several nefarious foes. The were led by an ace fighter pilot known only as Blackhawk. They are a legend among DC's rich history, even spawning a modern-day heroine, Lady Blackhawk.</p><p><em>Blackhawk</em> wasn't originally a DC comic. The character came from Quality Comics. It was not only one of their best sellers, but one of the best selling comic books. <em>Blackhawk</em> is unique in that DC kept its publishing consistent through their purchase of Quality Comics.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Plastic Man</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/plastic-man.jpg' /></figure><p>You'd be forgiven if you thought that <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/plastic-man/\">Plastic Man</a> had always been a DC character. He had a Saturday morning cartoon in the 70s, has been a member of the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/jla/\">JLA</a>, and was a regular fixture in more than a few ongoing series. However, Plastic Man's first stories were from Quality Comics.</p><p>His Golden Age origin has survived intact. Eel O'Brian was a criminal that was shot during a burglary. Some unknown chemicals got into the wound, giving him his <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-dc-plastic-man-vs-mr-fantastic/\">elastic, shape-changing powers</a>. He's gone on to remain one of DC's more popular humorous super-heroes, despite not starting with the publisher.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-comics-best-superhero-trials-ranked/\">DC: Top 10 Epic Trials Of Superheroes, Ranked</a></span></p>\n                        \n Stanford","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/blackhawk-and-the-ray.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn13@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-29-308_b09b150115a092fd.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/kid-eternity.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn13@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-43-321_690e346047620dd7.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/peacemaker.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn17@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-38-815_af4f98c8674f495d.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/sarge-steel.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn30@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-43-491_bf55df945f42e900.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/son-of-vulcan.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn19@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-39-503_b7087abc2bcf55a6.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Ted-Kord.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn70@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-43-005_f66c458493b482b3.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/the-ray-dc-comics-version.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn58@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-40-631_2415f2481a855ea9.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/uncle-sam.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn16@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-35-677_a81195952551b744.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Max-Mercury.jpg":null,"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/blackhawk-american-flag.jpg":null,"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/plastic-man.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn1@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-41-903_dff61d1ccac5abfc.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989074},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"5 Times Batman Went Undercover And It Worked (And 5 Times It Didn't)","link":"https://www.cbr.com/batman-undercover-worked-vs-didnt-comparison/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/5-Times-Batman-Went-Undercover-And-It-Worked-And-5-Times-It-Didnt.jpg\"/></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/batman/\">Batman</a> has quite a few tricks stored away in his utility belt or locked up in the Batcave, but his gadgets aren't the only tools at his disposal, as he is also a master of disguise who has gone undercover many times over the course of his crimefighting career with more than a few acting skills he picked up from Alfred.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/batman-best-fight-knightfall-ranked/\">Batman: 10 Best Fight Scenes From Knightfall, Ranked</a></span></p><p>Batman has created new identities on the fly in order to get more information or infiltrate his enemies, and he has spent years building up alternate personas and identities that have actually gained some respect in the criminal underground, however, Batman isn't always that successful when he goes undercover in the field.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>Worked: Matches Malone</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/matches-malone-display.jpg' /></figure><p>The real <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/matches-malone\">Matches Malone</a> was a waterfront mob boss that Batman had been observing for months as he hoped to sway him to working with him, though when Malone was killed in private by a ricochet while firing at Batman, another opportunity presented itself.</p><p>Batman hid Malone's death and took over the identity, using Malone's already established rep to help him track down <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/ras-al-ghul\">Ra's al Ghul</a>'s agents, though that was only the first of many times Matches Malone would make an appearance in the criminal underworld.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Didn't: Matches Malone</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/BATMAN-UNDERCOVER-War-Games.jpg' /></figure><p>While the Matches Malone identity would remain a useful alias of Batman's to help get information from the criminal underworld, it was also at the center of one of the biggest failures of Batman's career during the \"War Games\" storyline.</p><p>After Stephanie Brown/<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/spoiler\">Spoiler</a> had been fired as <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/robin\">Robin</a>, she attempted to launch one of Batman's plans that would have brought Gotham's gangs under the control of Matches Malone, though as she didn't know Batman was Malone, he never appeared, Spoiler was killed (but later returned), and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/black-mask\">Black Mask</a> assumed control of Gotham's underworld.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Worked: Superman</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/BATMAN-UNDERCOVER-Superman.jpg' /></figure><p>Batman and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/superman\">Superman</a> have exchanged costumes a few times to confuse enemies or help keep secret identities secret, though one of the most memorable came during a date night with Superman and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/lois-lane\">Lois Lane</a> to celebrate <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-catwoman-batman-saved-life-ended/\">Batman's engagement with Catwoman</a>.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fights-batman-won-should-have-lost/\">10 Fights Batman Won (But Realistically Shouldn't Have)</a></span></p><p>The foursome (Lois Lane rounded out the trio)  attempted to enjoy a town fair in their civvies but were rejected due to the \"Superhero Night\" theme, so they switched costumes in order to gain entrance without arousing suspicion. The stakes were low on this undercover \"mission,\" but it was a fantastic look at the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/batman-superman-greatest-meetings-worlds-finest/\">relationship between the World's Finest</a> and their significant others.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Didn't: Skullface</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/BATMAN-UNDERCOVER-Skullface.jpg' /></figure><p>When Roman Sionis/Black Mask returned to Gotham and reassembled the False Face Gang, he began to attack Wayne companies and kidnapping executives like <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/lucius-fox\">Lucius Fox</a>, which forced Batman to go undercover to save his friend.</p><p>He wore a blond wig and a scar to gain entrance to the gang, though Black Mask then gave him a Skull mask and named him Skullface. Skullface worked alongside the False Face Gang until he was forced to blow his cover to save Fox's life, revealing Bruce Wayne under the wig. Thankfully <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/batman-every-robin-debut-year-chronological-order/\">Robin arrived to save the day</a> at the last minute, and Wayne was \"saved\" by Batman.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Worked: Hawkman</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/BATMAN-UNDERCOVER-Hawkman.jpg' /></figure><p>After President <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/lex-luthor\">Lex Luthor</a> called for the arrest of Superman with a one billion dollar bounty that brought in leagues of criminals and even manipulated superheroes, Batman joined his BFF to stop Luthor and clear Superman's name.</p><p>However, the duo was almost stopped by <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/shazam\">Shazam</a> and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/hawkman\">Hawkman</a> who returned to the White House with prisoners in tow. However, it was revealed that <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/batman-superman-failures-comics/\">Superman and Batman</a> had traded places with Shazam and Hawkman, respectively, and they were able to breach the White House's defenses and end Luthor's presidency.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Didn't: Sir Hemingford Gray</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/BATMAN-UNDERCOVER-Sir-Hemingford-Gray.jpg' /></figure><p>After his confrontation with <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/bane\">Bane</a> left him injured and confined to a wheelchair during the <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/knightfall\">Knightfall</a></em> event, he was forced to fly halfway around the world on the search for his kidnapped doctor and lover, Shondra Kinsolving.</p><p>Wayne was able to follow her trail to England, where he used the identity of Sir Hemingford Gray to infiltrate her <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/batman-characters-introduced-during-knightfall/\">adopted brother Benedict Asp</a>'s manor, and while he was able to fool his way in, his shock at seeing Shondra in the manor forced him to slip and blow his cover, destroying the Gray identity while also losing Shondra temporarily.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Worked: Super Cyborg Cyborg Superman</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/cyborg-superman.jpg' /></figure><p>A confrontation between <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/cyborg\">Cyborg</a>, Superman, and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/cyborg-superman\">Cyborg Superman</a> occurred in the <em>DC Cybernetic Special</em> which was interrupted by the arrival of Super Cyborg Cyborg Superman, an amalgamation of the three characters from an alternate reality.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-cyborg-superman-worst-things/\">The 10 Worst Things Cyborg Superman Has Ever Done</a></span></p><p>\"SuCCS\" proved his identity with a Wiki page and helped distract Cyborg Superman enough to take him out with the help of Superman, where he revealed that Super Cyborg Cyborg Superman was actually Batman in disguise, though the idea had actually come from a <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/justice-league-new-cyborg-superman/\">real alternate reality merger of the characters</a>.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Didn't: Lefty Knox</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/BATMAN-UNDERCOVER-Lefty-Knox.jpg' /></figure><p>Batman briefly went undercover as a henchman known as Lefty Knox, whose discernible feature was a metal hook that replaced his left hand, which actually hid <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-batman-best-gadgets-inventions-rebirth-new-52/\">Batman's grappling hook</a> if needed for a quick escape.</p><p>Batman had created the Knox identity in order to get in close to Doctor Aesop's gang, though when <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/catwoman\">Catwoman</a> saw Lefty on the run from Aesop's goons, she intervened to save him after recognizing that he was actually Batman, inadvertently ruining his planned operation though she later helped take down the fable-obsessed criminal.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Worked: Jack Shaw</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/BATMAN-UNDERCOVER-Jack-Shaw.jpg' /></figure><p>After <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/arkham-asylum\">Arkham Asylum</a> was destroyed and forcibly relocated to Wayne Manor, Batman was forced to take the identity of a recently deceased homeless military vet named Jack Shaw in order to get inside the newly-christened Arkham Manor to solve a series of murders.</p><p>The Shaw identity was successful in allowing Batman to move unimpeded through Arkham Manor, and while he almost was forced to break character when dealing with the guards, he was able to solve the murders and \"escape\" from Arkham, keeping Jack Shaw alive to use again in the future. Batman gave the real Shaw a private military burial in thanks for the use of his name.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Didn't: Trey Malone</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/BATMAN-UNDERCOVER-Trey-Malone.jpg' /></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-batman-superpowers-used-while/\">Other Batman's have occasionally used the same tricks</a> to go undercover as well, with <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/batman-beyond\">Batman Beyond</a></em>'s Terry McGinnis creating his own take on his mentor's secret alias when he was forced to go undercover with Terminal's new gang of Jokerz.</p><p>McGinnis disguised himself as Trey Malone, son of the legendary Matches Malone, though his cover was quickly blown by Terminal, who had gone to high school with Terry and recognized him almost instantly. Terry was able to gear up as Batman and stop Terminal, but the short-lived Trey Malone identity was busted.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/batman-beyond-classic-villains-should-appear/\">Batman Beyond: 10 Classic Batman Villains That Should Make An Appearance</a></span></p>\n                        \n
