+0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Featured-Best-Summit-War-Saga.jpg","linkMd5":"7cabdd48cce99860941b4bdf629b9e66","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn8@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-29-491_b1a01b4fe2e5d798.webp","destWidth":1800,"destHeight":900,"sourceBytes":58324,"destBytes":58324,"author":"Suzail Ahmad","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Featured-Best-Summit-War-Saga.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn8@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-29-491_b1a01b4fe2e5d798.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/Amazon-Lily-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn83@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-35-389_b0979084e41d1a1b.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Luffy-Sabo-Ace.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn82@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-37-657_a258e20a76335a54.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Ace-Impel-Down.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn57@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-34-106_6161f9a024bda0c3.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/09/One-Piece-Sabaody-Archipelago-arc-Luffy-Celestial-Dragons.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn2@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-43-304_b4956ef8e4c873fb.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Whitebeard-using-the-tremor-fruit.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn52@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-35-987_d15fa78fa0f086da.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989066},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"5 Reasons Why Obi-Wan Was a Better Teacher to Luke (& 5 Reasons Why Yoda Was Better)","link":"https://www.cbr.com/obi-wan-vs-luke-vs-yoda-comparison/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Featured-5.jpg\"/></figure><p>Star Wars' <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/luke-skywalker/\">Luke Skywalker</a> had two amazing mentors during his <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/jedi-legends-anakin-defeat-lose/\">Jedi</a> training - <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/obi-wan-kenobi/\">Obi-Wan</a> and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/yoda/\">Yoda</a>. The legendary Knights helped <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/anakin-skywalker/\">Anakin</a>'s son to both grow as a human being and develop fully as the mighty Force-wielding warrior that went on to save the galaxy from the Empire's reign.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-obi-wan-kenobi-fan-art/\">10 Inspiring Pieces of Obi-Wan Kenobi Fan Art</a> </span></p><p>The <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-superheroes-survive-order-66-star-wars/\">Order 66</a> survivors each had a part to play in the protection and teaching of Luke and they performed admirably at the difficult but vital tasks that they were burdened with. Here are 5 reasons why Obi-Wan was Luke's best teacher and 5 why Yoda was superior to Kenobi in terms of being a Jedi Master.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>Obi-Wan: He Protected Luke for 19 Years</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Obi-Wan-Protecting-Luke.jpg' /></figure><p>Obi-Wan's longest-lasting mission was to guard Luke on his father's home planet of <a href=\"https://screenrant.com/star-wars-facts-trivia-tatooine/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Tatooine</a> until he was ready to begin his Jedi path. Becoming an exile and abanding one's former self was not nearly as difficult as <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/obi-wan-kenobi-toughest-fights-star-wars-history-ranked/\">the fights he had to survive</a> there. Fending off Tusken Raiders as well as assassins such as <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/darth-maul/\">Darth Maul</a> himself and in all likelihood going through a great number of other tough battles will likely be the focus of the upcoming Obi-Wan Kenobi-centered TV series.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Yoda: He Helped Luke to Develop His Full Potential</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Yoda-Helps-Luke-to-Unleash-His-Full-Potential.jpg' /></figure><p>When Luke first arrived on Dagobah and met the master that would help him develop into a threat that would challenge both Vader and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-darth-sidious-anakin-skywalker-top-villain/\">the Emperor</a> he was nothing more than an experienced pilot who has barely used the Force. Through the Grand Master, Luke developed his <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-lesser-known-force-powers-abilities/\">telekinesis abilities</a>, skill to channel the mystical power in a more focused way, lightsaber mastery, and athleticism. It was a long, yet fruitful training that started in <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/star-wars-the-empire-strikes-back/\">The Empire Strikes Back</a></em> (1980) and ended during the <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/star-wars-return-of-the-jedi/\">Return of the Jedi</a></em> (1983).</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Obi-Wan: He Set Luke On the Right Path</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Obi-Wan-Sets-Luke-on-the-Right-Path.jpg' /></figure><p>If it wasn't for the intervention of Obi-Wan and his decision to reveal his true identity as well as some of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-skywalker-family-members-powerful-legends-canon/\">Luke's family history</a>, the young Force-sensitive Skywalker wouldn't have found the strength or the inspiration to leave his home in search of justice for his murdered relatives.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-darth-vader-obi-wan-final-duel-fan-art/\">Star Wars: 10 Spectacular Fan Art Pieces Portraying Darth Vader &#38; Obi-Wan's Final Duel</a> </span></p><p>Kenobi showed the ambitious but lost boy from Tatooine that there is a greater destiny waiting for him, one that went beyond picking up power converters and taking care of a farm.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Yoda: He Didn't Abandon Luke Before He Was Ready</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Yoda-Left-Luke-When-He-Was-Ready.jpg' /></figure><p>Obi-Wan did a lot of things right while watching over Luke but one flaw in his actions was the fact that he abandoned him through the sacrifice that he made on the Death Star in <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/star-wars-a-new-hope/\">A New Hope</a></em> (1977). Yoda never left Luke but quite the opposite. The great Master died of old age and lived long enough to be able to praise his apprentice as \"ready\" and fully prepared to face his two formidable opponents. Most importantly, these weren't just words of comfort; they were the truth - as the final battle between the Jedi and the two Sith proved.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Obi-Wan: He Helped Luke Trust in the Force</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Luke-Believes-in-the-Force.jpg' /></figure><p>Yoda might have turned Luke into the powerful Jedi that he was always meant to become but the crucial step of believing in the Force was taken entirely with the help of Obi-Wan. Vader's son first felt the mystical power when he was practicing with his father's lightsaber under Kenobi's guidance. The ultimate proof of the powerful bond Luke had with the Force came in the most crucial moment of all - when he destroyed the Death Star by firing two perfect <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-most-powerful-ships/\">X-Wing</a> shots, again, after heeding Obi-Wan's advice.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Yoda: He Warned Luke of the Emperor</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Yoda-Warns-Luke-About-the-Emperor.jpg' /></figure><p>The real danger for Luke wasn't Vader but rather the villain who was pulling his strings - Palpatine. With his dying words, Yoda gave his last apprentice a crucial warning that allowed Luke to resist <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-powerful-jedi-turned-dark-side/\">the dark side and the Sith's persuasions</a>.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-evil-yoda-fan-art/\">Star Wars: 10 Spine-Chilling Pieces of Evil Yoda Fan Art</a> </span></p><p>Yoda, more than any other Jedi was familiar with what the feeling of facing Darth Sidious was like, following their epic confrontation in <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/star-wars-revenge-of-the-sith/\">Revenge of the Sith</a></em> (2005). Little did Sidious know that his <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-force-users-who-lost-to-rivals/\">greatest rival</a> had successfully trained the Jedi who achieved the antagonist's undoing.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Obi-Wan: He Protected Luke From Dangerous Truths</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Obi-Wan-Protected-Luke-from-Harsh-Truths.jpg' /></figure><p>In an act of compromise with his own Jedi values, Obi-Wan lied to Luke when it came down to the truth regarding his father and sister. Regardless of how unfair such a choice seemed at first, it was undeniably the right one. Luke would have been too conflicted and unfocused in a confrontation with Vader and therefore - vulnerable since at the time he had failed to complete his training. These precious bits of information might also be <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-shadiest-things-obi-wan-kenobi-has-done/\">the reason behind Obi-Wan's choice</a><strong> </strong>to die at the hands of Vader - so that they remain out of his reach.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Yoda: He Told Luke About His Sister</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Yoda-Tells-Luke-About-His-Sister.jpg' /></figure><p>As he was dying, Yoda revealed the existence of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/beautiful-fan-art-pieces-leia-jedi/\">another member of the Skywalker family</a> to Luke not just because he had the right to know but also because Luke was now becoming the last Jedi and in a way - the leader of their cause.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-obi-wan-darth-maul-rivarly-fan-art/\">Star Wars: 10 Fan Art Pieces Paying Tribute to Obi-Wan and Darth Maul's Decades-Old Rivalry</a></span></p><p>Yoda was a great leader not simply because of his wisdom and incredible power but also because of the way he never ignored the bigger picture and preserved hope for future generations even when he was hiding in the shadows.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Obi-Wan: He Led Him to Yoda</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Obi-Wan-Tells-Luke-to-go-to-Yoda.jpg' /></figure><p>The Rebellion's survival and success greatly depended on Obi-Wan, and preserving his Master - Yoda hidden and safe was one of the most important missions he had to succeed in. The final act of service with which he contributed to the Jedi cause was giving Luke the secret location of the last surviving member of the fallen Republic's <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-dumbest-decisions-jedi-council-made/\">Jedi Order</a>. In many ways, Obi-Wan's journey after the rise of the Empire was much harder than Yoda's.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Yoda: He Revealed the Flaws of the Dark Side</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Yoda-Wanrs-Luke-of-the-Dark-Side.jpg' /></figure><p>One thing that Anakin lacked was fear of the dark side and Yoda made sure that Luke has a clear understanding of its terrifying dangers. The test in the cave, the constant warnings, and discussions regarding the Sith's flawed beliefs that were part of Luke's training on Dagobah prepared him and helped him deny the persuasions of Vader and the Emperor in all of their meetings. Luke was the perfect man for the job of defeating the Sith - <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-most-powerful-loyal-jedi-sith/\">he was prepared to die rather than give in to evil</a>.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/star-wars-vs-marvel-villains-who-would-win-lose-against-yoda/\">Star Wars Vs. Marvel: 5 Villains Who Would Crush Yoda (&#38; 5 He Would Effortlessly Destroy)</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 20:30:20 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Featured-5.jpg","linkMd5":"3076a2a6ccf47b766e33850b48bed75d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn84@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-29-501_9ae915a37427d18c.webp","destWidth":1710,"destHeight":900,"sourceBytes":171468,"destBytes":171468,"author":"Deyan Angelov","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Featured-5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn84@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-29-501_9ae915a37427d18c.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Obi-Wan-Protecting-Luke.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn34@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-34-038_642ea09f77844b8a.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Yoda-Helps-Luke-to-Unleash-His-Full-Potential.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn1@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-34-169_ccebc7956d32c278.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Obi-Wan-Sets-Luke-on-the-Right-Path.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn57@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-39-080_236eebb8bbf7687e.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Yoda-Left-Luke-When-He-Was-Ready.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn24@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-42-581_4b85e4bb128c1bbe.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Luke-Believes-in-the-Force.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn11@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-40-342_e8cd041c67972415.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Yoda-Warns-Luke-About-the-Emperor.jpg":null,"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Obi-Wan-Protected-Luke-from-Harsh-Truths.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn75@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-43-888_9277657df2e1f38e.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Yoda-Tells-Luke-About-His-Sister.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn50@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-39-029_328a2a931e518160.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Obi-Wan-Tells-Luke-to-go-to-Yoda.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn22@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-34-031_c78915c9d6a95ce6.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Yoda-Wanrs-Luke-of-the-Dark-Side.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn51@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-36-696_fb230b2b9e8f1c19.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989071},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Mass Effect vs Dragon Age: How BioWare's Flagship Series Compare","link":"https://www.cbr.com/mass-effect-dragon-age-bioware-series-compared/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/mass-effect-dragon-age.jpg\"/></figure><p>Since releasing <em>Baldur's Gate </em>in 1998, Canadian game developer BioWare become one of the premiere RPG developers. Working with massive franchises like <em>Star Wars </em>and creating original series like <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/mass-effect/\">Mass Effect</a> </em>and <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/dragon-age/\">Dragon Age</a> </em>has kept BioWare relevant for the last two decades.</p><p>The developer's two longest-running original franchises, <em>Mass Effect </em>and <em>Dragon Age</em>, are often compared by both casual and hardcore fans. While both of BioWare's big franchises contain consistent elements, like well-developed companions and massive fictional worlds to explore, each franchise handles these in unique ways. Both series appear similar on the surface, but diving just beneath the surface reveals what makes each franchise distinct.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dragon-age-inquisitions-romanceable-characters-ranked/\">Dragon Age: Inquisition's Romanceable Characters, Ranked</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-combat.png\"/></figure><p><em>Mass Effect </em>and <em>Dragon Age </em>both focus on squad-based combat, with players controlling their own custom-made character and commanding a small number of followers. Both series let players freeze the battle at any time to pull up a radial menu, which allows them to use abilities and issue commands in the heat of battle. This makes the player character feel like a true leader, able to strategize and lead their unique team.</p><p>However, the similarities end there. <em>Dragon Age</em> focuses on close-range combat, ranged combat with bows or magic, and micromanaging your squad to achieve victory. Players can switch between controlling squadmates and programing the behavior of AI-controlled heroes to gain a tactical advantage over the enemy. Meanwhile, <em>Mass Effect</em> adds a heavy dose of third-person shooter gameplay to the equation, which makes moment-to-moment combat feel fast and hectic. In general, <em>Mass Effect</em>'s combat feels fast and natural, <em>Dragon Age</em>'s combat is slower and more tactical.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mass-effect-andromeda-great-idea-poor-execution/\">Mass Effect: Andromeda - Great Idea, Poor Execution</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dragon-age-companions.jpg\"/></figure><p>Characters are the bread and butter of any good BioWare game, and both <em>Mass Effect </em>and <em>Dragon Age</em> boast huge casts of iconic and memorable characters that can join you throughout the game. However, each franchise handles the companion system a bit differently.</p><p><em>Dragon Age </em>games feature an approval system where companions may agree or disagree with the protagonist's actions. Constantly making decisions that an ally disagrees with will damage your relationship with them, making them less friendly to speak to and even making them abandon your crew altogether. <em>Mass Effect</em>'s morality system is less intense, with your squadmates usually agreeing with your decisions. Each companion leans towards either compassion or ruthlessness, but the player's actions will never actually damage their relationship with a follower.</p><p>The <em>Mass Effect </em>trilogy also focuses on a core group of companions. The six companions you meet in the first game become massive parts of the trilogy's story, with some of them returning in the following two games. While <em>Mass Effect 2 </em>introduces many new companions, <em>Mass Effect 3</em>'s team is comprised almost entirely of returning characters from the first two games.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mass-effect-shepard-illusive-man-tension/\">Mass Effect: Shepard and the Illusive Man's Tension, Explained</a></span></p><p>In contrast, the three <em>Dragon Age </em>games so far feature almost completely different casts. While there are a few companions that return in subsequent games, it is far less common than in the <em>Mass Effect </em>trilogy. This makes <em>Dragon Age</em>'s cast feel larger and more diverse, but also less intimate than the tight-knit group in <em>Mass Effect.</em></p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dragon-age-world.jpg\"/></figure><p>Both <em>Dragon Age </em>and <em>Mass Effect </em>feature breathtakingly detailed and unique worlds for players to venture through. <em>Mass Effect </em>is set in the Milky Way galaxy in the 22nd century, when humanity has discovered a method of interstellar travel that allows them to join a galactic community of various species. <em>Dragon Age </em>is set in Thedas, a dark fantasy world rife with political conflicts and horrifying monsters. Both franchises flesh out their intricate worlds using dozens upon dozens of in-game texts that make each world feel authentic.</p><p>Due to the differing nature of the universes, <em>Mass Effect </em>and <em>Dragon Age </em>allow players to explore their worlds in different ways. <em>Mass Effect</em> allows players to explore different planets, traveling between them on the spaceship <em>Normandy, </em>but typically only a small linear area of each planet can be explored. <em>Dragon Age </em>is much more open, with players able to explore large areas and venture between them at their leisure. This results in <em>Mass Effect</em>'s galaxy feeling larger overall, but <em>Dragon Age</em>'s world feeling more natural and real.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mass-effect-shepard-samara-ended-morinth-rampage/\">Mass Effect: How Commander Shepard &#38; Samara Ended Morinth's Rampage for Good</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/shepard-male-and-female.jpg\"/></figure><p>Even with interesting worlds and iconic supporting characters, every story needs a protagonist. The player character determines how the player experiences a game and allows them to immerse themselves in its world. As RPGs, <em>Mass Effect </em>and <em>Dragon Age</em> allow players to customize their character with a unique appearance, gender, personality and abilities. However, each franchise differs heavily in the treatment of their protagonists. The <em>Mass Effect </em>trilogy features a single protagonist, Commander Shepard, whose attributes and relationships can be imported across all three games. This gives the trilogy consistency, with other characters meeting and building relationships with them over multiple titles.</p><p>Meanwhile, each <em>Dragon Age </em>game features a new protagonist with a new origin story and different relationships. While this means that the games feel less closely connected, it allows players to experience new things in each title rather than feeling confined by past decisions. Players who feel compelled to continue Shepard's morality and abilities across the whole trilogy might be more likely to experiment with new races, genders or classes in the <em>Dragon Age </em>games.</p><p>Over two decades, BioWare's titles have transported gamers to fantastical worlds and iconic characters, with each franchise delivering a fresh experience. <em>Mass Effect</em> uses save files to form a cohesive story with recurring characters and a consistent protagonist, while <em>Dragon Age</em> tells a variety of stories from the epic world of Thedas. While fans may prefer one approach, it's clear that BioWare has created two of the greatest role-playing series in history.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">Keep Reading: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dragon-age-inquisition-witcher-3-better-rpg/\">Dragon Age: Inquisition Vs The Witcher 3 - Which RPG Is Better?</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 02:15:16 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/mass-effect-dragon-age.jpg","linkMd5":"26164f43debbcd7af7b31f01bee03faa","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn75@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-29-424_6782328d264fd1be.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":127658,"destBytes":127658,"author":"Thomas McNulty","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/mass-effect-dragon-age.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn75@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-29-424_6782328d264fd1be.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/mass-effect-combat.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn45@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-42-174_9408ca208ad7ed89.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dragon-age-companions.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn24@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-36-522_a0f84bf9abc65e76.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/dragon-age-world.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn40@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-42-709_1013d773ce65c43d.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/shepard-male-and-female.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn49@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-39-832_14598b4bcd9d7521.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989062},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Riverdale Boss Teases the Death of Archie Andrews in Season 5","link":"https://www.cbr.com/riverdale-roberto-aguirre-sacasa-teases-archie-andrews-death-season-5/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Riverdale-Archie-arrested-header.png\"/></figure><p>Since it premiered on The CW in 2017, one of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/riverdale/\">Riverdale</a>'s core characters has been Archie Andrews (KJ Apa). Like his friends, Archie has gone through many trials and tribulations throughout the show's run. However, Archie might not be on the show for very long after series creator and showrunner Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa teased the death of the iconic redhead in Season 5 of <em>Riverdale</em>.</p><p>Aguirre-Sacasa posted two uploads of the scripts for Season 5's first four episodes on Instagram. Three of the images feature panels from classic and modern Archie comics. However, the script cover for \"Chapter Eighty: Purgatory\" features the somber cover of <em>Archie 1941 </em>#5. Said cover sees Jughead, Betty and Veronica standing in front of a grave while an image of Archie in <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/riverdale-casting-sheet-season-5-archie/\">a solider's uniform</a> appears overhead.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/riverdale-lili-reinhart-covid-filming-like-prisoner/\">Riverdale: Lili Reinhart Says COVID Filming Makes Her ‘Feel Like a Prisoner’</a></span></p><iframe width=\"320\" height=\"320\" frameborder=\"0\" src=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/CEpI8zcDqXs/\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe><iframe width=\"320\" height=\"320\" frameborder=\"0\" src=\"https://www.instagram.com/p/CErvS7yDgSH/\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe><p>\"The #Riverdale Players Theatre continues with our next two table reads today via Zoom!!,\" Aguirre-Sacasa stated in the second upload's description. \"As we say goodbye to high school and hello to...???\" In both uploads, Aguirre-Sacasa included several emojis in the descriptions, with a skull and crossbones being among the mutual ones.</p><p>This isn't the first time Archie Andrews has experienced death. The character was famously killed off in an alternate reality story in 2014's <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/archie-sacrifices-his-life-to-save-kevin-kellers-in-life-with-archie-36/\">Life With Archie</a> #36<a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/archie-sacrifices-his-life-to-save-kevin-kellers-in-life-with-archie-36/\">,</a> sacrificing himself to save his friend Kevin Keller from an attempt on his life.</p><p>The synopsis for Season 5 of <em>Riverdale </em>can be found below:</p><blockquote><p><span class=\"blast mmt-sentence\">Season five of RIVERDALE will begin with our characters’ final days as students at Riverdale High.</span> <span class=\"blast mmt-sentence\">From an epic Senior Prom to a bittersweet Graduation, there are a lot of emotional moments and goodbyes yet to come—with some couples breaking up, as everyone goes their separate ways to college—or elsewhere.</span> <span class=\"blast mmt-sentence\">Then, we will redock with our gang as young adults, all returning to Riverdale to escape their troubled pasts.</span> <span class=\"blast mmt-sentence\">And life—and romance—will only be more complicated now that they’re in their twenties…</span></p></blockquote><p><span class=\"related-single next-single\">RELATED:  <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/riverdale-showrunner-pretty-little-liars-reboot/\">Riverdale Showrunner to Spearhead Pretty Little Liars Reboot</a></span></p><p><em>Riverdale</em> stars KJ Apa, Lili Reinhart, Camila Mendes, Cole Sprouse, Madelaine Petsch, Casey Cott, Vanessa Morgan, Mark Consuelos, Skeet Ulrich, Marisol Nichols and Madchen Amick. The series returns for Season 5 in January 2021 on The CW.</p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 18:28:56 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Riverdale-Archie-arrested-header.png","linkMd5":"ef9068e660f84404ba9d7a66b5d7d8b5","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn60@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-29-470_bed2dd6204ab17a0.webp","destWidth":1200,"destHeight":600,"sourceBytes":434538,"destBytes":434538,"author":"Colin Hickson","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/07/Riverdale-Archie-arrested-header.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn60@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-29-470_bed2dd6204ab17a0.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989074},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"INTERVIEW: Brian Henson Talks Bringing New Alien Talk Show, Earth to Ned, to the Small Screen","link":"https://www.cbr.com/brian-henson-interview-talk-show-earth-to-ned/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Earth-to-Ned-Ned-and-Cornelius.jpeg\"/></figure><p><em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/earth-to-ned/\">Earth to Ned</a></em> is a brand-new talk show on <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/disney-plus/\">Disney+</a> hosted by Ned, a blue alien with four arms, and his sidekick Cornelius. Ned was sent to invade Earth but went a different direction after he fell in love with humans, and especially our planet’s most valuable resource: celebrities. Now, aided by their spaceship’s AI BETI and the tiny, comical CLODS, Ned and Cornelius beam famous folks onto the bridge of their ship for interviews in which Ned strives to learn more about different aspects of human culture. Some of the stars who do their best to get Ned up to speed in the show's first 10-episode season include RuPaul, Joel McHale, Andy Richter, Kristen Schall and Billy Dee Williams. This fun and unique take on the traditional late-night talk show comes from the brilliant minds at the Jim Henson Company, and while its beloved characters from <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-muppets/\">The Muppets</a> and <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/sesame-street/\">Sesame Street</a></em> have been a part of the pop culture landscape for decades, Ned and his cronies are brand new -- and every bit as fun and lovable as Kermit the Frog or Elmo.</p><p>In an exclusive interview, CBR spoke to Brian Henson, an executive producer on <em>Earth to Ned</em>, about the long road Ned’s taken to the small screen, the creation of the show's puppets and their personalities and how improvisation became a vital part of puppeteering at the Jim Henson Company.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-not-too-late-show-with-elmo-exactly-what-we-need/\">The Not-Too-Late Show with Elmo Is Exactly What We Need Right Now</a></span></p><p><strong>CBR: Where did the idea for <em>Earth to Ned</em> come from?</strong></p><p><strong>Brian Henson:</strong> Well, I've sort of been working on it for a while, actually, for years. I love the idea. I love the idea of somebody who's completely ignorant looking at mankind and trying to figure them out, and trying to figure out people. So, that was sort of at the heart of it, so that led us to aliens, aliens hosting a talk show. And over the years, at one point  it was aliens reviewing what was on television and stuff like that, but then it became the talk show, which was a much, much more fun and richer area to play with.</p><p>But the idea also was, I wanted to do something that felt and looked like a late-night talk show format, but we definitely made it super family-friendly, because we knew we were on a streamer, there is no time that it is aired, it's available on the streamer. But the idea of doing that late-night talk show format, but not having it be sort of cynical or sarcastic or too cool for school, I wanted to just be really positive. So that sort of guided us in the developing of the personality of Ned that he just loves humanity. You know, he was sent here to destroy the planet and he just can't do it, because he starts watching TV and he loves people.</p><p>And he wants to <em>be</em> a great person. He loves people, and he has gotten it all wrong, which is part of what's fun. So he's made all these assumptions that he understands mankind and he understands the way people think and what they do, but he's getting it wrong all the time. But everything delights him, all of the absurdity of people just delights him. And that feeds into a lot of the interviews where very quickly the guest celebrities figure out that Ned just keeps getting it wrong so they're able to tell him how society really works and how people really interact. And that's just kind of a great and fun place to be as the show, the content, because it kind of allows us to laugh at ourselves instead of getting angry at ourselves. So, it's a positive look at the absurdity that is our existence. And I just loved that.</p><p>So once we have that as Ned, then we're like, we need a cool sidekick. And actually originally, it was Ned and the sidekick and they were reviewing television. But then we developed BETI, the artificial intelligence, and the CLODS are really there for just ridiculous comic relief and I just thought it was part of the suspension of disbelief. They're very, very simple puppets and a lot of fun. So then the show then becomes a talk show, but it has very rich [characters] and their relationships are a lot of fun. So you also get this overarching storyline as you're watching these characters interact. So it's a talk show, but it's also the show behind the scenes of the talk show at the same time.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Earth-to-Ned-Brian-Henson.jpeg\"/></figure><p><strong>While there is that overarching story, as you said, the interactions in the actual talk show segments seem very spontaneous. How much of the show is scripted?</strong></p><p>Yeah, almost never is a guest on script. So, all of the interviews are 100% improvised, and Cornelius and Ned are improvising. But they have a set of questions and topics that we know relates to the storyline of the episode.... But both the field pieces and the interviews are almost never scripted at all.</p><p>And then the pieces between the interviews are scripted. So when it's Ned and Cornelius talking before a guest comes in, then we're scripted. We don't stay rigid to the script. Improvising puppets is something that I've been having so much fun with and started back in like 2006 with my show, <em><a href=\"https://www.henson.com/puppet-up.php\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Puppet Up! -- Uncensored</a></em>. So my puppeteers have been training in improv comedy for over 10 years, so I really liked the idea of improvising animatronic creatures because it's just something that we had never done.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/fraggle-rock-reboot-ordered-series-apple/\">Apple Orders Fraggle Rock Reboot to Series</a></span></p><p><strong>I've seen <em>Puppet Up!</em>; it's really phenomenal.</strong></p><p>And these guys all came off of that. So Colleen [Smith] who's BETI and Paul Rugg who's the voice of Ned and Michael Oosterom was the main puppeteer on Cornelius. Basically all the puppeteers came out of <em>Puppet Up!</em>.</p><p><strong>How did the team develop the different personalities for the different characters?</strong></p><p>Well, we had a very exhaustive audition process to figure out, primarily, the pairing of Cornelius and Ned. But like I said, the type of content we wanted guided us a lot in creating the personality of Ned. So we knew a lot about what we wanted Ned to be. He's very optimistic. He's ignorant and excited about all things human. And we knew that he was also a military general, that this was the worst job; he should never have been made a military general because he's the last guy that should have done that. And that guided us. Then we're like, \"Well then how did he get the job?\" Well because his dad is the Admiral of the Fleet, and that's how he was given a ship. And he's sort of coming out; Ned has had a life of suffering because he's been forced to be what he isn't comfortable being, and then he's gotten to Earth, and now he wants to be a person. It's opened him up so that he's now a new person, and so excited about being a person.</p><p>And then Cornelius really is a military lieutenant, and so we were saying for Cornelius, this is all a huge sidetrack that he doesn't particularly like, he doesn't know why we've done it. But then what we knew was his arc was he was going to learn more about himself and more about humanity, and that really, he's the one that grows the most. And then BETI is just the cynical artificial intelligence that really was running a battleship, and really, the only purpose is to be destroying planets, and this is all a ridiculous waste of time. And she just thinks Cornelius and Ned are idiots.</p><p><strong>What about the creation of the physical puppets? Even just the eyes on Ned and Cornelius are remarkably articulated. Is there new technology being used to make the puppets so intricate?</strong></p><p>...The route that came into creating Ned was when I created Richfield for <em>Dinosaurs.</em> I loved that character. He can't move, he's stuck behind a desk, but because of that you can bring to life this really big character. And I loved Ritchfield. I loved Ritchfield so much, that's what led us to creating Pilot on <em>Farscape</em>. Pilot was also really big, and Pilot turned out to be really my favorite animatronic character that we've ever created.</p><p>So Ned, the physical creation of the puppet, there's a lot of what we learned on Pilot that goes into Ned. He's stuck behind a desk, he's got four arms, he's got a really big head, and that allows you to do more with motors, and that allows him to be more expressive. So yeah, I guess, the route to Ned was Richfield via Pilot into Ned.</p><p>And then Cornelius is more akin to characters that we've done more often, where it's a hand puppet but with an animatronic enhancement. Neither of them have any CG enhancements going on. So, they are 100% animatronic, which is a little old school in a fun way.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Earth-to-Ned-CLODS.jpeg\"/></figure><p><strong>How many people does it take to operate Ned and Cornelius?</strong></p><p>Ned takes six.</p><p><strong>Wow.</strong></p><p>And they're improvising. And actually, that's the one thing that I thought might have turned out to be impossible. I was a little worried... I didn't know if six people could ever get on the same page and improvise together. And it was really hard. For the first couple weeks, it was really tough. And then they all just sort of gelled, and then it became the most fun. All of the puppeteers on <em>Ned</em> all said this is the most fun they've ever had puppeteering because of trying to work with a group of six. It's just delightful and unpredictable. And we also kind of programmed it into his personality a little bit that he's a little bit all over the place because I knew there's six people. He can't be a precise performing character... it'll never work, so he's a little bit all over the place.</p><p>And then Cornelius is three, which is something we do often. So Cornelius is the main puppeteer is doing one hand and the head, and so that's very like the Muppets. And then the second puppeteer is just doing the other hand, and the third puppeteer is doing all of the facial features. And that's a combination we've done quite a bit, so that's pretty predictable. And then BETI is... Colleen is basically performing BETI on her own, that's a real-time animated character. And then all the little CLODS... basically, they're simple little rod puppets. They're styled after a puppet that my dad [Muppets creator, Jim Henson] made well before I was born. And I don't know what the name of it was but he made these little creatures with these extending plastic stretched necks, and they just had a little nose and eyes.... He made them probably in the mid 1950s. And so I was basically borrowing from that heritage with that puppet that my dad made and sort of updating it.</p><p><strong>So which came first the physical puppets or their personalities? It sounds like the personality came first and then the look came later. Is that correct?</strong></p><p>Yeah, a little bit. I mean, you have the concept of the character first.... This is how much I knew before we started drawing the character: He loves mankind, he just adores mankind, that was where it started. Then we started drawing. So then we were drawing and developing the personality kind of simultaneously. And then by the time we were building the character..., we had a three-page full description of his personality.</p><p><strong>It's really amazing how fully realized the characters seem to be as soon as they appear on the show. Is creating those believable personalities something you have a formula for or do the personalities naturally emerge as you create the characters?</strong></p><p>No. It's why I started <em>Puppet Up!</em> The reason I started <em>Puppet Up!</em> is because our puppeteers had become so script-based that it was taking way too long for characters to feel fully rounded. Because they were just... coming up with a voice. A puppet was assigned, they would come up with a voice and then they would do the script, and that was just not creating rich enough characters. And so that's why we started the whole improvising inside of our company was because with a good improviser, the moment they start improvising in the scene you believe their character is fully realized, they have a whole history, a whole life, and that, I knew, was what we needed. So that's why we shifted all of our training to improv and puppeteering training since 2006. That's the way we train all of our puppeteers now. We train them in improv comedy and puppetry.</p><p>And in the old days... when my dad was alive, we only trained in puppetry, and for every 20 people -- and I did a lot of the training for my father -- for every 20 people we trained, we maybe had two good performers. And it would be the people that what my dad would call, \"could ad-lib,\" because we never thought about improvising. But the ones that were good enough that they could actually ad-lib tended to be the best ones.</p><p>They were the ones who could develop a new character. Because... this is the way we would find new characters [on <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-muppet-show/\"><em>The Muppet Show</em></a>]. We'd have an episode where cows walk in, say three things and then walk out. And then if we loved the cow, then the cow would be written to come back in in another show and then another show and another show, and then eventually the cow might become a main character on <em>The Muppet Show</em>. And so what we were finding is it's only those performers who could ad-lib who could make that cow funny, who would make that cow unforgettable in the first three lines.</p><p>So anyway, that's what pushed us to improvising and why I love so much the idea of improvising in this show. I love these aliens... improvising because that gives you that character richness. It does mean you do overshoot. Most of our interviews were one-hour interviews. You know, they have to be so that you can play around [with] different topics, and then in the end you tighten it all up.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-muppets-2015-isnt-train-wreck-remembers/\">The Muppets' 2015 Series Isn't the Train Wreck Everyone Remembers</a></span></p><p><strong>Recently there have been several talk shows hosted by Muppets. Elmo has a talk show, Miss Piggy had a talk show for a while. What is it about the talk show format that seems to work for these characters?</strong></p><p>I think it basically comes from puppets work well with celebrities. So that's the first thing, because puppets can get celebrities to relax and not worry about being too cool for school, you know. Celebrities don't worry about humiliating themselves when they're with a puppet, and so they open up a lot more. So that's just always been true and... <em>The Muppet Show</em> and <em>Sesame Street</em>, even in the early years, that's where it became clear that the puppets work really well with celebrities. And you know, nobody's doing variety shows anymore, so that format may be on the rebound, it may be coming back. But honestly, we didn't know that Elmo had a talk show when we started making <em>Ned</em>. And Miss Piggy's talk show, you mean the ABC series <em>Muppets</em>, right?</p><p><strong>I do.</strong></p><p>And yes, but we didn't really think that we were treading too close to that. Ours is actually much closer to a real talk show.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Earth-to-Ned-Ned-with-Irwins.jpeg\"/></figure><p><strong>Unlike something with Elmo or Miss Piggy, though, this is a whole new character that celebrities might not be familiar with. Was it easy to get stars to participate?</strong></p><p>Yes, but not everyone. It's because it is very normal that when you have a new talk show it's all about who's the host, and what has the host done, can you show us some material on the host, because we want to protect our clients. So when agents and managers weren't able to see anything on this, literally, we had to cast quite a few of our guests when Ned was only a drawing, when he was still being built. So I guess, truthfully, it meant that our guests tend to be more daring, where they didn't mind that they didn't really know what they were getting into.... By the time we finished shooting the first episode, we already had cast all the episodes that we shot. So, we literally didn't cast anyone who had really seen Ned, maybe three guests were cast after they could see Ned and see him interviewing somebody else....</p><p><strong>It's actually a really fun group of guests.</strong></p><p>And that's what we were looking for is fun. Fun is exactly the word we were looking for. People that would have fun, who would be daring and do things that were unexpected and all of that. I couldn't be happier with the results of all the guests. They were really terrific.</p><p><strong>There've been a lot of revivals recently with legacy characters. There's been a new <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/muppets-now/\">Muppet show</a>, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/Fraggle-Rock/\"><em>Fraggle Rock</em></a> is coming back, but Earth to Ned is really fun because it's a completely original new character. Are there any plans to create other original characters for other shows?</strong></p><p>...People are loving rebooting things, and we're doing it... but we tend to do it not as remakes. You know, like <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-dark-crystal-age-of-resistance/\">The Dark Crystal </a></em>that was prequel, the miniseries was prequel. Yeah, we're always developing original stuff. I love doing original stuff. It's harder to sell. I thank Dan Silver at Disney+ for loving this one. And... part of the problem with our kind of shows is creating Ned and Cornelius costs a ton of money, so you can't really do a test, you can't do a pilot. The only way it makes sense financially is if you make a whole series, even though you don't even have the characters yet. And so that's hard for a channel, for an outlet to take that kind of risk. And I just think, ...kudos to Disney+ that they liked the idea of doing something so original.</p><p><em>All 10 episodes of Earth to Ned are available to stream now on Disney+</em>.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/muppets-now-scooter-interview/\">Muppets Now's Scooter Talks Up the New Disney+ Show</a></span></p>\n                        \n 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Assassin's Creed Manga, Blade of Shao Jun, Hits in Early 2021","link":"https://www.cbr.com/assassins-creed-manga-blade-of-shao-us-release-viz-february-2021/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/assassins-creed-header.jpg\"/></figure><p><em>Assassin's Creed: Blade of Shao Jun</em>, Minoji Kurata's manga based on the popular <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/assassins-creed/\">Assassin's Creed</a> series of video games, is getting a localized release in the United States this February from Viz Media.</p><p><em>Blade of Shao Jun</em> follows Shao Jun, a Master Assassin of the Chinese Brotherhood of Assassins who lived during the 1500s. Set in the year 1526, the manga sees Shao Jun -- China's last Assassin -- return to her homeland to seek vengeance for the deaths of the others at the hands of the new Emperor. In other words, it takes place during the same time as the 2015 video game <em>Assassin's Creed Chronicles: China</em> -- the first entry in the <em>Assassin's Creed Chronicles</em> sub-series of games -- which starred Shao Jun as the main protagonist. It also takes place two years after the events of <em>Assassin's Creed: Embers</em>, the 2011 animated short film that saw Shao Jun travel to Europe and meet legendary Assassin Ezio Auditore.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dark-horse-assassins-creed-valhalla-prequel-comic/\">Dark Horse to Publish Assassin's Creed Valhalla Prequel Comic</a></span></p><p>Blade of Shao Jun was originally published in <em>Sunday GX</em> magazine as <em>Assassin's Creed: China</em> in October of 2019, with the first collected volume arriving in Japan earlier this summer. The cover, as well as Viz's official synopsis for the localized version of the volume, can be found below.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Assassins-Creed.jpg\"/></figure><blockquote><p><u><b>Assassin's Creed: Blade of Shao Jun, Vol. 1 by Minoji Kurata</b></u></p><p>A gripping manga based on Ubisoft’s Assassin’s Creed Chronicles: China video game, featuring iconic Assassin Shao Jun. Unveil a tale that will engulf the world.</p><p><i>1526 AD—China is ruled by the Great Ming Empire. Though the empire flourishes, the winds of the new Emperor’s political purge are sweeping over the land, and turmoil is brewing. With the decimation of her comrades, Shao Jun has become China’s last Assassin. After escaping to Europe, she has now returned alone to her homeland. Her purpose: vengeance!</i></p><p>Pub date: February 16, 2021</p><p>List price: $14.95</p><p>ISBN13: 9781974721238</p></blockquote><p>Written and illustrated by Minoji Kurata, <em>Assassin's Creed: Blade of Shao Jun</em> Vol. 1 goes on sale in the United States Feb. 16, 2021 from Viz Media.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/assassins-creed-ezio-joins-afk-arena/\">Assassin's Creed's Ezio Joins AFK Arena</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 21:07:20 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/assassins-creed-header.jpg","linkMd5":"f9769dd2b36d51aa53deadd092799234","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn9@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-29-159_770b03e60a1d8b3a.webp","destWidth":1200,"destHeight":600,"sourceBytes":97112,"destBytes":97112,"author":"Noah Dominguez","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/assassins-creed-header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn9@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-29-159_770b03e60a1d8b3a.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Assassins-Creed.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn43@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-35-276_87dca6811a2d710a.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989070},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Warner Bros. She also mentioned that, before production began, there were contingencies in place to deal with a coronavirus outbreak. \"I think it would have been naïve to think we wouldn’t have certain cases on certain productions,\" she added.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-batman-production-remains-paused/\">No, The Batman Hasn't Resumed Production</a></span></p><p>Sarnoff later said that the way production is being done on <em>The Batman</em> won't change unless a medical solution is released that would keep cast and crew members safe. \"Instead, we are just proceeding as if there won’t be and resuming production as safely as we can,\" she said.</p><p>After a long delay beginning in March of this year, <em>The Batman</em> officially restarted production in late September, only to be shut down a few days later after Robert Pattinson's diagnosis. Currently, there is no official word on when production will resume.</p><p>Starring Robert Pattinson as Bruce Wayne/Batman, <em>The Batman</em> will show the Caped Crusader going against one of the character's most famous rogues, The Riddler. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-batman-matt-reeves-trailer-4k-resolution/\">A first official look</a> at the film was shared by director Matt Reeves at DC FanDome.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-batman-warnermedia-ann-sarnoff-covid-19-shutdown/\">The Batman: WarnerMedia's Ann Sarnoff Comments on COVID-19 Shutdown</a></span></p><p>Directed by Matt Reeves and written by Reeves and Mattson Tomlin, <em>The Batman</em> stars Robert Pattinson as Bruce Wayne/Batman, Andy Serkis as Alfred Pennyworth, Jeffrey Wright as James Gordon, Zoë Kravitz as Selina Kyle/Catwoman, Colin Farrell as Oswald Cobblepot/The Penguin, Paul Dano as Edward Nashton/The Riddler, John Turturro as Carmine Falcone and Peter Sarsgaard as District Attorney Gil Colson. However, there's another musician that had an influence on the show: Billy Joel.</p><p>During an interview with <a href=\"https://www.inverse.com/entertainment/the-boys-season-2-seth-rogen-eric-kripke-interview\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Inverse</a>, showrunner Eric Kripke discussed how Hughie's (Jack Quaid) love of Joel ended up influencing the character's emotional arc. \"It started as a bunch of ad-libs in Season 1 about this kind of running joke that involved how much Huey loves Billy Joel, and a lot of it came from Jack Quaid,\" Kripke said. \"I think there was an original line of staring up at the Led Zeppelin poster on the ceiling and we changed it to Billy Joel because he wouldn't have a Zeppelin poster. He would have a Billy Joel poster.\"</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-boys-season-2-introduces-gecko/\">The Boy Introduces Its Most Macabre Supe Yet When Starlight Takes a Dark Turn</a></span></p><p>Joel recently posted about this news on Twitter, noting that \"We Didn't Start The Fire\" is a song that plays a major role in Season 2. The song featured heavily in Season 2's trailers.</p><iframe width=\"320\" height=\"320\" frameborder=\"0\" src=\"https://twitter.com/billyjoel/status/1301897813069045760\" frameborder=\"0\"></iframe><p>In the same interview, Kripke discussed how several of Joel's songs play a role in Season 2, as they reflect Hughie's various moods. He also said that Joel was more than willing to let his songs be used in the show. \"We had to get Billy's permission because it was like a lot of Billy Joel, and to his credit, he has shown a remarkable sense of humor and seems like a great guy approved all of it.\"</p><p>Streaming now on Amazon Prime Video<em>, The Boys</em> stars Karl Urban as Billy Butcher, Jack Quaid as Hughie, Laz Alonso as Mother's Milk, Tomer Kapon as Frenchie, Karen Fukuhara as the Female, Erin Moriarty as Annie January, Chace Crawford as the Deep, Antony Starr as Homelander, Aya Cash as Stormfront and Simon Pegg as Hughie's dad. New episodes of Season 2 arrive Fridays.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-boys-season-2-premiere-episodes-drop-early/\">The Boys: Season 2's Premiere Episodes Drop on Prime Early</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 17:19:10 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Hughie-in-The-Boys.jpg","linkMd5":"4e5c7ec395aeff436f0cb8f57aa1bc67","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn80@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-29-545_829d4a04a6f7c496.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":103214,"destBytes":103214,"author":"Collier Jennings","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Hughie-in-The-Boys.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn80@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-29-545_829d4a04a6f7c496.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989076},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Todd McFarlane's Spawn #310 Variant Cover Introduces Ninja Spawn","link":"https://www.cbr.com/spawn-310-todd-mcfarlane-cover-reveal-ninja-spawn/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Spawn-310-McFarlane-Variant-Ninja-Spawn-Header.jpg\"/></figure><p><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/spawn/\">Spawn</a> creator Todd McFarlane has revealed his variant cover for issue #310, which introduces the character of Ninja Spawn -- who will factor into the record-breaking comic book's actual story in the coming months.</p><p>\"Sneak peek at <em>Spawn</em> #310 cover!\" McFarlane wrote on <a href=\"https://twitter.com/Todd_McFarlane/status/1301656739532603392?s=20\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Twitter</a>. \"Folks! I want to show you how awesome my cover of Ninja Spawn turned out for the upcoming <em>Spawn</em> #310 issue!! He'll be on the cover of Spawn #310 and then will join the story inside a few months later!\" Notably, this new iteration of Ninja Spawn for the comic book seems to carry rather different design than McFarlane Toys' old Ninja Spawn action figures.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/spawn-309-image-comics-second-print/\">Spawn #309 Goes Back to Print After Reorder Numbers Hit Five Figures</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/EhBp5ulU8AAK-Ti.jpg\"/></figure><p>Featuring a main cover by Francesco Mattina and an additional variant by Björn Barends, <em>Spawn</em> #310 is slated to go on sale later this month. \"Spawn is on the hunt for someone, or something, insidious!\" the official synopsis reads. \"Demons hiding among humans! Secret dealings with Big-Pharma! Dark plans are about to be exposed! There is a storm coming, and Spawn is at the center.</p><p>Written by Todd McFarlane and illustrated by Jim Muniz, Spawn #310 goes on sale Sept. 30 from Image Comics.</p><p><span
