Although both films feature the same character, each is radically different, offering unique interpretations of Superman for its audiences. Which is the definitive film?</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>SUPERMAN RETURNS: TRADITION</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Action-Comics-Cover-Superman-Returns.jpg' /></figure><p><em>Superman Returns</em> loosely followed the main plot points and characterizations of the first two Reeve films. The film was a nostalgic and reverent trip down memory lane for fans of those films, filled with character details like Lois’ struggle with smoking and Lex’s obsession with real estate.</p><p>Moreover, the film paid homage to generations of the Man of Steel’s mythology. The film had costuming and a visual aesthetic reminiscent of the 1940’s Fleischer cartoons. Clark Kent was an overly clumsy milquetoast. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/superman-jimmy-olsen-best-worst-versions/\">Jimmy Olsen was a wide-eyed, good-natured photographer</a>. And the filmmakers even threw in some well-known “Super-isms” like “look, up in the sky- it’s a bird, it’s a plane, it’s...!”</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>MAN OF STEEL: CONTEMPORARY</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Superman-in-HandCuffs.jpg' /></figure><p>A big part of<em> Man of Steel</em>’s appeal was its break from the cinematic portrayals of Superman that had come before, as well as its placing of the hero in an updated and contemporary world.In <em>Man of Steel</em>, an alien being with the power to juggle cars like grapefruits and shoot laser beams from his eyes was approached with a certain degree of trepidation, and not welcomed with open arms as a new messiah, as he was in previous <em>Superman</em> films.</p><p>Perhaps most refreshingly, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-things-make-no-sense-about-lois-lane/\">a resourceful young journalist</a> was able to figure out Superman’s identity quite easily!</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>SUPERMAN RETURNS: ROMANCE</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Lois-Superman-Superman-Returns.jpg' /></figure><p>A good film is built on the relationships of its characters, and <em>Superman Returns</em> was no different. Centering around the shaky romantic relationship between the Man of Steel and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/superman-10-best-lois-lane-stories-of-all-time/\">Lois Lane</a>, the film explored the rift between the two since Superman's disappearance, as well as what the future might possibly have in store for them as parents.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dccomics-superman-lois-lane-most-romantic-moments/\">10 Most Romantic Moments Between Superman &#38; Lois Lane</a></span></p><p>The preponderant focus on romance rather than action is something fans and moviegoers criticized, feeling the film was too melodramatic and slow at times for a movie about the world's first and greatest superhero. However, the drama provided a nice layer of substance and texture to the characters.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>MAN OF STEEL: BATTLE SCENES</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Man-of-Steel-Superman-Flight-Fight.jpg' /></figure><p>It's not every day a moviegoer gets to see two people punch each other through skyscrapers or destroy a small Midwestern town in its entirety. Those who decried <em>Superman Returns</em>' lack of battle scenes got what they craved and more in <em>Man of Steel</em>. The film finally depicted what could be possible in terms of an onscreen fight between people with <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-comics-strongest-kryptonians-ranked/\">Kryptonian power levels</a>, which resulted in the destruction of most of downtown Metropolis. This carnage was not only thrilling (and also a little difficult) to watch, but also proved the impetus for Batman’s actions in <em>Dawn of Justice</em>.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>SUPERMAN RETURNS: SUPER-DAD</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Superman-Son.jpg' /></figure><p>The formula for storytelling when it comes to the Man of Steel hasn’t really changed much in the last eighty-odd years. He’s a reporter. He’s from Krypton and was raised in Kansas. He’s vulnerable to <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/superman-kryptonite-types-effects/\">kryptonite</a>. He saves people from danger, especially Lois Lane.</p><p>Most of the elements readers and moviegoers see as iconic were added years after Superman’s debut. For example, he only gained the ability to fly a few years after his first appearance. <em>Superman Returns</em> sought to add another element to the narrative stew by including Jason White as Superman’s biological son. The idea was interesting if not well-received, and has since been introduced in the comics in the form of Jonathan Kent, Superboy.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>MAN OF STEEL: EARLY WANDERINGS</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Man-of-Steel-Beard.jpg' /></figure><p>Before <em>Man of Steel</em> gave Superman the <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/unanswered-questions-batman-begins-dc-nolan-alfred-christian-bale/\">Batman Begins</a></em> treatment by showing the hero’s early wanderings, no film had depicted Clark Kent’s early adulthood. Sure, 1978’s <em>Superman</em> had shown Clark leaving the farm and eventually reaching the North Pole where he accidentally created the Fortress of Solitude, but it didn’t really go into detail about his travels.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/superman-dc-comics-man-of-steel-birthright-origin-comparison/\">Superman: 5 Reasons Why Birthright Is His Definitive Origin (&#38; 5 Why It's Man Of Steel)</a></span></p><p><em>Man of Steel</em> filled in those gaps, illustrating how a young Clark Kent took odd jobs on an oil rig or as a waiter as he explored his place in the world in light of his special powers. This colored-in an important part of the character’s life and added to his depth in the eyes of the audience.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>SUPERMAN RETURNS: HUMOR</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Superman-returns-Lex-Luthor-Brushes-his-Teeth-Daily-Planet-conference.jpg' /></figure><p>One of the major criticisms leveled against <em>Man of Steel</em> (as well as all of Zack Snyder’s DCEU offerings) was that it was too dark and somber in tone, lacking the optimism and humor with which the character had come to be associated.</p><p>Thankfully, <em>Superman Returns</em> made more of an effort to infuse its narrative with a little comedy. Whether it was Lex Luthor’s toothpaste-filled recognition of Lois Lane, Kitty Kowalski’s reluctance to let Superman fly after saving her, or Jimmy Olsen’s nervous musings, <em>Superman Returns</em> was chock-full of lighthearted and amusing moments.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>MAN OF STEEL: SUPER-PHYSIQUE</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Hnery-Cavil-Superman-Physique.jpg' /></figure><p>Nothing against Christopher Reeve or Brandon Routh, who both worked notoriously hard to attain their spandex-ready physiques, but the svelte and slender Superman doesn’t really match the comic book depiction. In the comics, Superman is presented as quite muscular, somewhere between ripped solid and jacked up.</p><p>Whatever regimen Henry Cavill was on to gain his Super-physique, it worked perfectly. The actor managed to capture Superman’s look to a tee, from his chiseled pecs to his bulging biceps to his rock-hard abs. Christopher Reeve had us believing a man could fly; Henry Cavill had us believing a man could lift the whole world on his perfectly formed shoulders!</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>SUPERMAN RETURNS: HOPE</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Superman-Returns-Space.jpg' /></figure><p>For all its faults,<em> Superman Returns</em> is a film about hope. It’s hope that drives Superman to the remains of Krypton, hope that allows people to accept Superman’s return to Earth, and hope that helps Lois &#38; Superman rekindle their friendship in wake of the rift that grew between them.</p><p>In many ways,<em> Superman Returns</em> captures the hopeful aspect of the character infinitely more than <em>Man of Steel</em>’s curt discussion of the “S” on his chest. <em>Superman Returns</em>’ bright and upbeat portrayal features a Superman who inspires hope in the people of the Earth, whereas<em> Man of Steel</em>’s gritty and somber depiction inspires ambivalence or a modicum of distrust.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>MAN OF STEEL: FOUNDATIONS OF THE DCEU</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Man-of-Steel-1.jpg' /></figure><p>Ever since Marvel Studios weaved together its own interconnected universe of films, fans have been clambering for DC Comics to do the same. With eagle-eyed fans spotting a Wayne Enterprises logo on a satellite damaged in a Zod/Superman battle, fans knew it was only a matter of time before the first steps were taken for a DC extended universe, and<em> Man of Steel</em> was quickly established as that first step. Although the critical success of the DCEU <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dcau-things-live-action-movies-can-learn-animated-cinematic-universe/\">has been much maligned</a>, it wouldn’t even exist if not for this film.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/batman-superman-failures-comics/\">5 Times Batman Couldn't Save The Day (&#38; 5 Times Superman Couldn't)</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 18:30:49 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Brandon-Routh-Henry-Cavill-Superman.jpg","linkMd5":"ea5046a1b997d3f2c1a5545cd45c5b18","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn13@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-30-413_1363a74bf04c684f.webp","destWidth":1710,"destHeight":900,"sourceBytes":173104,"destBytes":173104,"author":"Julian Beauvais","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Brandon-Routh-Henry-Cavill-Superman.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn13@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-30-413_1363a74bf04c684f.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Action-Comics-Cover-Superman-Returns.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn48@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-37-539_c0bb4651a1d61483.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Superman-in-HandCuffs.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn26@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-38-970_01e0f926a9ffd856.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Lois-Superman-Superman-Returns.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn65@2020_1/2020/09/05/06-56-41-472_78300c56ef5acfc7.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Man-of-Steel-Superman-Flight-Fight.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn10@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-37-997_bad9428da5889ce7.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Superman-Son.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn30@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-34-013_ffc2f800fdc11cae.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Man-of-Steel-Beard.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn34@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-38-245_b8b82842bc8b63de.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Superman-returns-Lex-Luthor-Brushes-his-Teeth-Daily-Planet-conference.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn48@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-42-723_a4f115746ca6ce92.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Hnery-Cavil-Superman-Physique.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn96@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-40-981_57d1e4b19cce6b90.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Superman-Returns-Space.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn78@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-40-121_f23c232b6bc3cbea.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Man-of-Steel-1.jpg":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989074},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Lucifer Delivers the Show's Biggest, Most COSMIC Fight Yet | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/lucifer-season-5-part-1-finale-celestial-fight-biggest-yet/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Lucifer-Season-5-Header.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><strong>WARNING: The following article contains major spoilers for <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/lucifer-tv\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">Lucifer</a> Season 5, Part 1, available now on Netflix.</strong></em></p><p><em>Lucifer</em> may be a television series based on a comic book, but it's different than your usual comic book show. This isn't <em>Arrow</em> or <em>Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.</em> -- the characters in <em>Lucifer</em> may be celestial beings, but none of them are superheroes in any sense of the word. It's not a series filled with super-heroics and elaborate fight sequences. Still, <em>Lucifer</em> occasionally features a good brawl between its characters, whenever the situation calls for it.</p><p>The series' fight scenes are usually far and between, given that it spends more time focused on the mystery of whatever case Lucifer and Chloe and currently on. But in Season 5, the Netflix series finally delivers something it never has before: an extended, no holds barred brawl between no less than four cosmic-level beings that easily ranks as <em>Lucifer</em>'s best fight scene yet.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lucifer-why-the-show-goes-black-white-for-an-entire-episode/\">Lucifer: Why The Show Goes Black &#38; White For An Entire Episode</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Lucifer-Season-5-fight.jpg\"/></figure><p>In the Season 5 finale of <em>Lucifer</em>, \"Spoiler Alert,\" Lucifer rescues Chloe after she was kidnapped by Michael. Once they are safely back at the precinct, Amenadiel arrives to talk to Lucifer about Charlie, but Lucifer needs to talk to Chloe first. However, everything changes when time inexplicably stands still for everyone except Lucifer and Amenadiel.</p><p>Soon, Michael also arrives to keep toying with his two brothers, fueling more fear into Amenadiel by using his newborn son against him. Eventually, Amenadiel's anger gets the best of him, and he finally unleashes his angel might on his archangel brother.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lucifer-michael-disappointing-season-5-villain/\">Lucifer: Michael Is A Disappointing Season 5 Villain</a></span></p><p>At the same time, Maze also joins the party, revealing that she has joined Michael's side after he promised to get her a soul. What then follows is an extended fight sequence between two teams: Maze and Michael versus Lucifer and Amenadiel, in the middle of a police precinct that is frozen in time. The confrontation is easily the longest in the show's five-year run, and also its most hard-hitting.</p><p>Here, all four celestial beings don't hold back. Maze fights to kill, and it takes all of Lucifer's skills to keep the lethal demon at bay. But one can also notice that the devil is slightly holding back, given that he is fighting one of his oldest friends. However, even he has his limits and eventually, he makes sure she stays down.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lucifer-season-5-reveals-why-devil-can-be-hurt/\">Lucifer Reveals Why the Devil Can Be Hurt</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Lucifer-S5E2-Michael-Wings.jpg\"/></figure><p>The battle between Michael and Amenadiel is also spectacular. These are two angels battling it out, and every single one of their hits makes the camera shake. It's a great way to show off the characters' raw power. On top of that, every character has his or her own fighting style, which also makes for a nice touch. The fight also features a cheer-worthy team-up between Luci and Amenadiel, showing the brothers standing by one another.</p><p>And if all that wasn't enough, things get even more biblical when all three angels whip their wings out, only to be interrupted by a bright light that precedes the arrival of their father, God himself. While the battle ends before a clear winner can be decided, one thing is clear: <em>Lucifer</em> has just set an impressive bar for itself.</p><p><em>Lucifer stars Tom Ellis as Lucifer Morningstar, Lauren German as Det. Chloe Decker, D.B. Woodside as Amenadiel, Rachael Harris as Dr. Linda Martin, Kevin Alejandro as Det. Dan Espinoza, Lesley-Ann Brandt as Mazikeen Smith and Aimee Garcia as Ella Lopez. Season 5, Part 1 is available on Netflix now.</em></p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/lucifer-where-does-eve-fit-in-season-5/\">Lucifer: Where Does Eve Fit Into Season 5?</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 02:45:06 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Lucifer-Season-5-Header.jpg","linkMd5":"6fab3bad74088d5280c74531dda939be","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn18@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-29-556_9f8c80aee214d9ed.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":129632,"destBytes":129632,"author":"Ian Cardona","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Lucifer-Season-5-Header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn18@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-29-556_9f8c80aee214d9ed.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/Lucifer-Season-5-fight.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn66@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-37-572_dfaa763eda0a2498.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Lucifer-S5E2-Michael-Wings.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn64@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-31-469_4180d8579590969e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989061},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Magic: The Gathering - The Cult of Rakdos Guild, Explained | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/mtg-cult-rakdos-guild-explained/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/rakdos-2.jpg\"/></figure><p>In <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/magic-the-gathering/\">Magic: The Gathering</a></em>, the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dungeons-dragons-ravnica-explained/\">plane of Ravnica</a> is home to ten two-colored guilds, and the guild with the heaviest reputation is the Cult of Rakdos. This guild combines red and black mana in an insane, bloody circus of spectacles and horrors, fire and glee. Everyone fears the Rakdos guild, and its members will improvise a stunning performance anywhere they can find room. All of Ravnica is their stage.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/rakdos-4.jpg\"/></figure><p>A number of Ravnica's other guilds have clear goals and methods. The <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mtg-boros-legion-guild-explained/\">Boros Legion</a> is dedicated to maintaining law and order on the street at swordpoint, while the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/magic-the-gathering-selesnya-guild-explained/\">Selesnya Conclave</a> seeks to unite all people with the power of nature and the Worldsoul. The <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/magic-the-gathering-izzet-league-explained/\">Izzet League</a> and the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mtg-ravnica-simic-combine-guild-explained/\">Simic Combine</a> want to experiment endlessly with artifice and evolution, respectively. As for the Rakdos Cult, the ultimate plan is to have fun.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/magic-gathering-2021-release-schedule-set-titles/\">Wizards of the Coast Announces Magic: The Gathering Release Timeline Through 2021</a></span></p><p>This guild is not seeking to reshape Ravnica in its image or create a better future. Instead, the Cult of Rakdos is about the pleasure and carnage of the here and now. It's a deliberately short-sighted guild that acts first and thinks never. At first, this may seem like a fruitless endeavor, but Ravnica is a stifling and stressful place to be, and the people need an escape valve to let themselves run free and indulge their inner desires, even the darkest ones. The Cult of Rakdos is that escape valve, and it will accept anyone who shares its members' values. Sadism, hedonism, the love of spectacle and more are the cornerstones of this wild and brutal guild.</p><p>When times are tough and misery dominates the streets, even more people turn to the Rakdos guild so they can drown their woes in someone else's blood. Since killing fellow members is an option, the Rakdos guild has a high turnover rate. But the idea of letting go and going wild is so appealing to so many people that this guild can sustain its numbers through recruitment, making it a fluid and dynamic place to live. Perhaps a tightrope walker was juggling torches when he fell to his death on rusty spikes, so a new recruit can don his bloody outfit and resume the show right away. Or, if a devil cuts loose and massacres an entire audience, that's all right; there's a whole line of maniacs outside the door, waiting to replace them.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mtg-ravnica-golgari-swarm-guild-explained/\">Magic: The Gathering - Ravnica's Golgari Swarm Guild, Explained</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/rakdos-3.jpg\"/></figure><p>Humans are a major race of the Cult of Rakdos, and they are joined by an array of devils and imps, mischief-loving creatures that are experts in inflicting pain, setting everything on fire and, above all, putting on a good show. This guild is also home to many of Ravnica's demons, great beings of black and red mana that act as heavy cavalry during battles with rival guilds. A demon is perfectly willing to slaughter any ally who gets in the way of its attacks, and when a battle with the Rakdos is over, it's likely that almost <em>everyone </em>is dead, save the demons and their favorite minions. Goblins, rats, elementals and shades help fill the ranks of this guild.</p><p>The leader is Rakdos, an ancient red-black demon who was alive even before the Guildpact was signed 10,000 years ago. He is large and overwhelmingly powerful, but due to his age, he has high and complex standards about what makes for a good show. Only rarely does he emerge from his inner chambers in Rix Maadi, the central guild building, and when he comes along, he demands a good show. Outstanding performances are applauded, while poor ones are punished with a massacre -- thus creating a new show to enjoy. Many Rakdos guild members make it their personal goal to plan and put on a performance that entices Rakdos to join the party himself.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">Related: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mtg-ugin-life-powers-revealed/\">Magic: The Gathering - The Life and Powers of Ugin, Revealed</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/rakdos-1.jpg\"/></figure><p>Rakdos decks are aggressive and dedicate few resources to defense. Instead, they want to pressure the opponent from the start, and this guild's mechanics and creature designs reward proactive and reckless play styles. This guild first appeared in the <em>Dissention </em>set with the mechanic Hellbent, which rewards the player for having no cards in hand. Hellbent creatures might get extra abilities, and Hellbent instants and sorceries become more potent.</p><p><em>Return to Ravnica </em>brought back the Rakdos, this time with the Unleash ability found only on creatures. Such a creature may enter the battlefield with a +1/+1 counter and become larger than normal for its mana cost at the expense of being unable to block if it has any +1/+1 counters on it. This is a truly do or die mechanic, and it appears on big and small creatures alike. Some of these Unleash creatures get extra abilities if they have +1/+1 counters on them, such as trample.</p><p><em>Ravnica Allegiance </em>gave the Rakdos Spectacle, meaning any card with that effect may be cast for a (typically cheaper) alternate cost if an opponent lost life this turn. This encourages aggressive plays that turn the entire game into a carnival. Many of these cards give the caster bonus effects if the Spectacle cost was paid, on top of paying less mana overall.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/mtg-sideboard-against-modern-burn-decks-guide/\">Magic: The Gathering - How to Sideboard Against Modern Burn Decks</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 05 Sep 2020 00:15:37 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/rakdos-2.jpg","linkMd5":"c29ca3797307b91ad3bc81cfab4a8686","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn96@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-30-827_74ec522f1f5f70d0.webp","destWidth":2400,"destHeight":1200,"sourceBytes":327912,"destBytes":327912,"author":"Louis Kemner","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/rakdos-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn96@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-30-827_74ec522f1f5f70d0.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/rakdos-4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn62@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-34-034_2a8f2ff999aca37c.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/rakdos-3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn36@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-35-272_7bbd21bcad55fa7f.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/rakdos-1.jpg":null},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989065},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"X-Men: 5 Reasons Cyclops Deserves The Hate (& 5 Why He Doesn't)","link":"https://www.cbr.com/cyclops-most-hated-x-men-marvel-scott-summers/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/cyclops-featured-james-marsden.jpg\"/></figure><p>Scott Summers a.k.a. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/cyclops/\">Cyclops</a> is one of the most polarizing members of the <a href=\"https://screenrant.com/tag/x-men\">X-Men</a>, and this is nothing new. He was the first in comics, the leader of the team, when Professor X first put them together. He was also the most boring, the one who followed all the rules and seemed like the boring, perfect little boy scout.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"X-Men: Every Film &#38; TV Appearance of Cyclops, Ranked\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-cyclops-every-film-tv-appearance-ranked/\">X-Men: Every Film &#38; TV Appearance Of Cyclops, Ranked</a></span></p><p>There eventually became more and more reasons for fans to hate Scott Summers. He was spoiled, refused to listen to anyone else, and he thought he was the only one worth leading the team. Eventually, he became the opposite of his original self, going from the do-gooder to an all-out mercenary at times. But does he deserve so much hate from the fans?</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>DOES - HE WAS SANCTIMONIOUS</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/CYCLOPS-X2-X-Men-United.jpg' /></figure><p>Many fans disliked Scott Summers from the beginning. He was the one who wanted to follow all the orders and never wanted to break rank. However, he also looked down on other mutants, even if he never meant for it to appear that way. He was dismissive of those who were more freewheeling and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/wolverine-vs-cyclops-rivalry-explained/\">always had a cruel thing to say about Wolverine</a>. He just acted like he was better than everyone else, and that is never a good look.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>DOESN'T - HE WAS A GREAT LEADER</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Cyclops-Optic-Blast-feature.jpg' /></figure><p>While Cyclops was someone who seemed to consider himself better than everyone around him, there was a good reason for it. Professor Xavier put a lot of faith in Scott and put a lot of responsibility on his shoulders. He never buckled under pressure and was always one of the best leaders of the X-Men.</p><p>In later years, when Scott became more dangerous, he was still a great leader, making the hard decisions that others were unwilling to make, leading by example, and ensuring his team always had a chance to win.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>DOES - HE POUTED WHEN HE DIDN'T GET HIS WAY</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Jean-wolverine-cyclops-feautred.png' /></figure><p>If there is one thing that makes Cyclops one of the least liked members of the X-Men, it is his petulant attitude that leads him to pout when he doesn't get his way. He saw Wolverine as an alpha male and a threat and always treated him poorly as a result.</p><p>At one point, he was challenged for his leadership role by Storm, and they settled it by sparring in the Danger Room. Storm won, so Cyclops quit the X-Men, took his ball, and went home. He is a baby when he doesn't get what he wants.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>DOESN'T - HE BELIEVED IN THE CAUSE</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Cyclops-Death-Of-X.jpg' /></figure><p>There is a reason Professor X trusted Cyclops to lead the team as a young man. Cyclops believed in what Xavier was teaching. He believed in doing the right thing to protect mutants, not only today but in the future. He believed in doing anything necessary to make sure that the dream became a reality.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"X-Men: How Marvel Mashed Up Cyclops and Apocalypse\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-how-marvel-mashed-up-cyclops-and-apocalypse/\">X-Men: How Marvel Mashed Up Cyclops And Apocalypse</a></span></p><p>He was the one man who stood by Xavier through it all and rarely questioned him until later in his life when he realized Xavier's dream and the mutant cause was no longer the same. He still believed in the cause, though.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>DOES - HE WAS A TERRIBLE HUSBAND/BOYFRIEND</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/cyclops-emma-frost-header.jpg' /></figure><p>In the early days of the X-Men, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-cyclops-every-love-interest-ranked/\">Cyclops loved Jean Grey</a>, and they seemed like the ultimate super couple. However, Scott had some problems at that time and was a little too overly possessive, pushing her away more than once.</p><p>When she died, he ended up marrying a new woman in Madelyne Pryor, and the two were expecting a child. When <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-reasons-jean-grey-cyclops-scott-summers-x-men-best-comics-couple-terrible-together/\">Jean Grey turned out to still be alive, Cyclops left</a> Madelyne and his child. Later, when Jean died again, he moved on to Emma Frost, and when Jean was back again, he kept making poor decisions.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>DOESN'T - HE OVERCAME A TOUGH LIFE</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/cyclops-featured.jpg' /></figure><p>There is a reason that Cyclops is such a fearless leader and such a strong proponent of the mutant cause. He knows what it is like to grow up with a society that hates him. Unlike most mutants, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-cyclops-optic-blast-punch-dimension/\">Cyclops has no control over his powers</a> and has to wear his visor to keep them in check. No matter what he has done to help society, they have always turned on him. He has watched young mutants die, and humans hate them no matter what they do. Scott has a right to be bitter.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>DOES - HE SENT CHILDREN IN AS MERCS</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Cyclops-vs-Wolverine-from-Marvel-comics.jpg' /></figure><p>In <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-important-cyclops-stories/\"><em>X-Men: Schism</em></a>, the team splintered down the middle. By this time, Cyclops was 100-percent behind the black ops operations of a group like X-Force. He sent a young mutant to take out the Hellfire Club and ordered her to kill them all.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"X-Men: 5 Reasons Why Cyclops’s '80s Costume Is His Most Iconic (&#38; 5 Why His ‘90s Look Is)\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-5-reasons-why-cyclopss-80s-costume-is-his-most-iconic-5-why-his-90s-look-is/\">X-Men: 5 Reasons Why Cyclops's '80s Costume Is His Most Iconic (&#38; 5 Why His '90s Look Is)</a></span></p><p>He sent X-23, a young teenager at the time, to kill people, knowing how her past tormented her. This led to Wolverine and Cyclops in a fearsome brawl, and it ended with the two men leading their own X-Men, with Cyclops still sending in children to kill.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>DOESN'T - HE IS FEARLESS</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/clean.v1-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>There is something to be said about a leader who is willing to do anything he asks someone else to do. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/cyclops-best-better-marvel-comics-leader-captain-america/\">Cyclops is that kind of leader</a>. He will charge headstrong into battle. He will take on any enemy, no matter how big or how strong. He will make the tough decision, and while some might think he makes bad choices for his teammates, he is willing to follow them into the depths of hell to save mutant-kind. Cyclops is a fearless leader and doesn't deserve hatred.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>DOES - THE MUTANT MARTYR</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Cyclops-Burns-Charles-Xavier-To-Death.jpg' /></figure><p>During the Avengers V. X-Men storyline, the two sides battled for Hope, with the Avengers wanting to take her into protective custody and the X-Men believing she might save them all if she takes on the Phoenix Force.</p><p>What ended up happening the Phoenix took on members of the X-Men and <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/x-men-cyclops-most-devastating-optic-blasts/\">Cyclops was the last man standing after he murdered Professor X</a> and then surrendered to take his place at the mutant martyr. It was a move that made him a villain, and he did it just to reignite the mutants cause against humanity.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>DOESN'T - HE IS THE ULTIMATE X-MEN Member</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Cyclops.jpg' /></figure><p>There are a lot of people who represent what the X-Men are about. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-xmen-wolverine-cyclops-important-mutant/\">Wolverine is someone many count as a favorite</a>, but he isn't about the X-Men first and foremost anymore, as he took the Avengers side in the way against them. Storm is not around as much, and while Kitty Pryde is the heart of the team, she is not its face. When thinking of the X-Men, Cyclops is the face that leads the way. He is the ultimate X-Men member, and if fans love the X-Men, they should always respect Cyclops.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"X-Men: 5 Times Cyclops Saved The World (&#38;5 Times He Almost Ended It)\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/times-cyclops-saved-the-world-and-times-he-almost-ended-it/\">X-Men: 5 Times Cyclops Saved The World (&#38;5 Times He Almost Ended It)</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 20:30:02 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/cyclops-featured-james-marsden.jpg","linkMd5":"ce7479320b17fc106325d6b29641b327","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn20@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-31-254_fb7625ccef2eeba2.webp","destWidth":1700,"destHeight":850,"sourceBytes":193878,"destBytes":193878,"author":"Shawn S. Lealos","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/cyclops-featured-james-marsden.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn20@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-31-254_fb7625ccef2eeba2.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/CYCLOPS-X2-X-Men-United.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn7@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-36-601_78eb0baa60d557cb.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Cyclops-Optic-Blast-feature.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn25@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-34-014_77e32f77595b8b7d.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Jean-wolverine-cyclops-feautred.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn78@2020_1/2020/09/05/06-56-43-232_76e9b91e27f86447.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Cyclops-Death-Of-X.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn99@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-39-312_3532e23128d0b10c.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/cyclops-emma-frost-header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn42@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-41-183_e7528cea09bf2dd9.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/cyclops-featured.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn75@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-36-255_5399ddde6368bba3.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/05/Cyclops-vs-Wolverine-from-Marvel-comics.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn56@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-43-688_edb79530b1854e00.webp","https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/clean.v1-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn28@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-35-146_efe7258007bb0cd4.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Cyclops-Burns-Charles-Xavier-To-Death.jpg":null,"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/04/Cyclops.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn59@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-36-265_e24e0bc7dfad7289.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989074},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"Superman Just Crossed Batman's Dark Knight Line Without Blinking","link":"https://www.cbr.com/superman-dark-knight-mass-surveillance/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/superman-action-comics.jpg\"/></figure><p><strong><em>WARNING: The following contains spoilers for </em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/action-comics/\">Action</a><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/action-comics/\"> Co</a><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/action-comics/\">mics</a><em> #1024, by Brian Michael Bendis, John Romita Jr., Klaus Janson, Brad Anderson and Dave Sharpe, on sale now.</em></strong></p><p>It's hard to find a character more iconic of moral principles than <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/superman/\">Superman</a>. Over the years as the rest of the heroes at DC and Marvel grew darker, edgier, and more violent it was Superman who stood out as a slice of good old-fashioned American pie. But there are some lines he doesn't think twice about crossing are a major moral dilemma for some of his colleagues.</p><p>And in <em>Action Comics </em>#1024, Superman and his family spies on the entirety of Metropolis without a second thought.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Death Metal: A Twisted Batman Devises the Ultimate Way to Break Superman\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/death-metal-batman-breaks-superman/\">Death Metal: A Twisted Batman Devises The Ultimate Way To Break Superman</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Superman-Superboy-X-Ray-Vision-2.png\"/></figure><p>The breach of privacy comes on the heels of a death that rocked Superman to his core. The Deputy Chief of the Fire Department, <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/superman-melody-moore-red-mist-murder/\">Melody Moore, </a>recently made friends with Superman as the two saw hope for Metropolis amidst the corruption of the city that seemed to be everywhere. Superman helped Melody put out a few fires, as it were, and evidently that made her a target for the Invisible Mafia.</p><p>Adapting to new levels of discretion, organized crime in Metropolis developed into the Invisible Mafia as a response to Superman's absurd levels of surveillance. They form a comprehensive list of words they ban from their speech so that his super hearing will not detect him and only operate in facilities hidden from his prying x-ray vision. It turns out that they're just not discreet enough however, as killing Superman's pal Melody only spurs the superhero to sic his entire family on them.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"Superman Is Setting Up DC's Mystical CRISIS\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/superman-setting-up-dc-mystical-crisis/\">Superman Is Setting Up DC's Mystical CRISIS</a></span></p><p>Distraught for a moment by Melody's death, Superman immediately resorts to scanning the entirety of Metropolis with his super senses. He says that he is looking for blind spots or lead lining, trying to root out the Invisible Mafia wherever they are. Rather than admonish Superman for his breach in privacy, his whole family joins in. Both Superboys, Supergirl and even Brainiac 5 use their vast array of senses to comb across every detail of the city.</p><p>And the moral question doesn't even come up. In <em>The Dark Knight</em> the very question Superman ignores proved to be a major moral dilemma for the caped hero's counterpart. In that film, Batman used a type of sonar technology to turn every phone in Gotham into a spy network that allowed him to track down the Joker. Lucius Fox was so disgusted by the act he could not condone it and the technology was disposed of for being too much power for any one person to wield.</p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Dark-Knight-Lucius-Fox.jpg\"/></figure><p>But such a question does not even come up for Superman. Instead, all five superheroes begin pouring over every inch of the city (and quite possibly the planet) while even explicitly mentioning how the can see private citizens using the bathroom. It's reduced to something of a joke about how \"gross\" people are, but at the bottom, it's actually a pretty severe violation of civil liberties.</p><p>The comic does not seem interested in grappling with such a problem materially, and that only raises further questions about how often and casually Superman does this. Does he only resort to spying on the whole city when a close friend dies, or does he do it all the time? Considering how many other heroes are all too eager to help him, this moment is packed with disturbing implications, and this might be a perfect example where truth, justice and the American way don't all fit together as neatly as Superman so often would like.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a class=\"bc-title-link\" title=\"The Most Powerful Superman Is a DBZ-Like, Meta-Narrative Fusion Created by Dr. Manhattan\" href=\"https://www.cbr.com/most-powerful-superman-dbz-like-fusion-created-by-dr-manhattan/\">The Most Powerful Superman Is A DBZ-Like, Meta-Narrative Fusion Created By Dr. Manhattan</a></span></p><p><!-- Used for easily cloning the properly namespaced rect --></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 21:20:09 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/superman-action-comics.jpg","linkMd5":"7b78ed0f1b19c271de5fe45d89d002b2","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn25@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-31-269_a26b21ee0b33a422.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":176662,"destBytes":176662,"author":"Brenton Stewart","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/superman-action-comics.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn25@2020_3/2020/09/05/06-56-31-269_a26b21ee0b33a422.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Superman-Superboy-X-Ray-Vision-2.png":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn87@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-36-984_a4380ad5a41c6b91.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Dark-Knight-Lucius-Fox.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn46@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-36-689_40e2150f8d2ed014.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989069},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"10 Weird Facts About Supergirl | CBR","link":"https://www.cbr.com/dc-supergirl-weird-facts/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/supergirl-1.jpg\"/></figure><p>Supergirl is one of the most iconic characters in the DC Universe. Going by the moniker the Girl of Steel, Supergirl is the older cousin of Superman and also fled the doomed planet of Krypton and crashed onto Earth. Like her cousin, rather than turning evil, she would help the people of Earth and defend them against threats and harm.</p><p style=\"text-align: left;\"><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/supergirl-best-villain-general-zod-vs-lex-luthor/\">5 Ways General Zod Can Become Supergirl's Greatest Villain (&#38; 5 Lex Luthor Is Already More Diabolical)</a></span></p><p>The character has been around for decades and, as such, has been the subject of some of the weirdest and most <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-supergirl-makes-no-sense/\">bizarre tales in comic book history</a>. Fans of Supergirl should definitely be aware of some of these whacky footnotes in Supergirl’s long and breathtaking character history.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>Might Be Stronger Than Superman</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/pjimage-2-Cropped.jpg' /></figure><p>While the fact that Superman is often believed to be the most powerful superhero in the DC Universe, there is ample evidence to actually state that his cousin, Supergirl, is <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/supergirl-vs-superman/\">far stronger than the Man of Steel</a>.</p><p>The explicit example of this came in <em>Superman/Batman #19</em>, when Batman basically states that her powers exceed that of Superman. While Superman is certainly more experienced, in terms of raw power, Supergirl surpasses him.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Exists In The DCEU</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/Man-of-Steel-Superman-Reveal-Scoutship.jpg' /></figure><p>The DCEU went through stormy waters after the release of <a href=\"https://screenrant.com/tag/Justice-League/\"><em>Justice League</em></a>. However, things now appear to be looking up for the shared universe (and multiverse), hinting at a bright future for DC Comics movies.</p><p>One of the more interesting Easter eggs from <em>Man of Steel</em> was the empty Kryptonian pod on the crashed ship. A comic also showed that Supergirl indeed exists in this universe.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Fought Zatanna For An Abominable Snowman</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1B10B490-B03C-4192-87E8-2CBF97683CE6.jpeg' /></figure><p>The Silver Age of comics was one of the strangest in the history of the comic book genre. The era was full of whacky, strange stories in which characters ran into the strangest enemies and, sometimes, acted very outside of what many would term their character.</p><p><p style=\"text-align: left;\"><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-wonder-woman-batgirl-supergirl-best-trio/\">Wonder Woman, Batgirl, And Supergirl: Why They're The Best DC Female Trio</a></span></p></p><p>One of these stories saw Supergirl and Zatanna fighting over the abominable snowman, after the two superheroines arrived in the Himalayas to rescue the same man.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Honorary Amazon</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/Supergirl-and-Wonder-Woman.jpg' /></figure><p>The DC Universe leans heavily into Greek mythology, with <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/wonder-woman-vs-supergirl/\">Wonder Woman</a> being the biggest example of this. Wonder Woman is a demi-god who hails from an island known as Themyscira that is populated solely by Amazon warriors.</p><p>Despite being one of the most secluded and secretive communities in the DC Universe, Supergirl became an honorary Amazon in <em>Supergirl #9.</em></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Can See People’s DNA</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/supergirl-1.jpg' /></figure><p>One of the more interesting of The Kryptonian powerset is the supervision. This allows Kryptonians to see across great distances, even being able to see Krypton from Earth in some continuities.</p><p>However, in one issue of Supergirl<em>, </em>it is shown that Supergirl is able to use her vision to see peoples’ DNA, allowing her to tell people apart on a genetic level. There’s certainly no identity fraud with Supergirl.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Joined The Red Lantern Corps</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Supergirl-Red-Lantern.jpg' /></figure><p>The DC Universe has a whole set of ‘Lanterns’. Each different Lantern Corps relies on a different manifestation of energy, so the Green Lanterns use will, the Yellow Lanterns use fear, and the Red Lanterns use anger.</p><p><p style=\"text-align: left;\"><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/avatar-legend-korra-vs-dc-supergirl/\">Korra Vs Supergirl: Who Would Win?</a></span></p></p><p>Despite being a heroic character, fans might be surprised to learn that Supergirl was among the ranks of the <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-comics-supergirl-powers-abilities-weird/\">Red Lantern Corps</a> during a time in the New 52. The power of the Red Lantern Corps even doubled Supergirl’s powers, making her one of the strongest beings in the DC Universe.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>She Can Time Travel</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Supergirl-2.jpg' /></figure><p>As said earlier in this list, the Silver Age was one of the weirdest eras of comics. In addition to strange storylines, some characters even received powers that they are typically not perceived to possess in general continuity.</p><p>In <em>Action Comics #255</em>, Supergirl travels to the future and ends up meeting Tommy Tomorrow, helping to save his future parents in order to thank him after he saved her from a block of kryptonite.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>She Dated Her Horse</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Supergirl-Comet-the-Super-Horse.jpg' /></figure><p>Superpets aren’t uncommon in the DC Universe, with Krypto the Super Dog being the most notable of these. However, Supergirl also had her own pet, a Kryptonian horse known as Comet.</p><p>However, in a bizarre series of events, Comet ended up becoming a human and, strangely, Supergirl went on a date with him. This is certainly one of the strangest DC stories of all time.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Supergirl Clone</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/supergirl-matrix.jpg' /></figure><p>Clone sagas have a bad reputation in comics, with the Spider-Man clone saga still triggering a kind of PTSD in many comic fans today. However, there was a similar clone issue in DC Comics, with <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-comics-powerful-clones-ranked/\">Supergirl being replaced by a clone</a> for several years.</p><p><p style=\"text-align: left;\"><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/supergirl-movie-casting-best-actress/\">10 Actresses Perfect To Play Supergirl In The Movie</a></span></p></p><p>Naturally, this version of Supergirl is far from the heroic version that appears in comics today. Going by the name of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/superman-supergirl-best-worst-versions/\">Matrix Supergirl</a>, this version would replace the Kara Zor-El Supergirl for over a decade.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Power Girl</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Power-Girl-1.jpg' /></figure><p>The history of DC Comics can be incredibly confusing. The world was full of different universes and versions of characters, to the extent that the event ‘Infinite Crisis’ had to be brought in order to correct the balance and fix the DC continuity.</p><p>Power Girl is an example of this heavy DC use of the multiverse. <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dc-supergirl-vs-power-girl-who-would-win/\">Power Girl is, essentially, Super Girl</a> from Earth 2 and, through a cosmic accident, ended up arriving in the main DC universe and decided to stay.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/dceu-comic-stories-supergirl-film/\">DCEU: 10 Comic Stories We Want To See In The Supergirl Film (That Have Never Been Done In Live-Action)</a></span></p>\n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 22:00:37 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/supergirl-1.jpg","linkMd5":"de895a9477e02fc673587018a107a28e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn52@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-30-551_39317db4ae80fd71.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":155100,"destBytes":155100,"author":"Sam Hutchinson","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/supergirl-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn52@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-30-551_39317db4ae80fd71.webp","https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/pjimage-2-Cropped.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn13@2020_5/2020/09/05/06-56-34-150_cd07fa2185709437.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/Man-of-Steel-Superman-Reveal-Scoutship.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn64@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-35-244_e91c441505ee31b6.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/1B10B490-B03C-4192-87E8-2CBF97683CE6.jpeg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn78@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-34-127_e0941bf8b1728807.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2018/02/Supergirl-and-Wonder-Woman.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn50@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-34-036_c7e92b43a94fc17f.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Supergirl-Red-Lantern.jpg":null,"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Supergirl-2.jpg":null,"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Supergirl-Comet-the-Super-Horse.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn62@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-40-785_51290bcdadc94b14.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/10/supergirl-matrix.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn37@2020_6/2020/09/05/06-56-38-996_446727aa6584cdbc.webp","https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Power-Girl-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn66@2020_1/2020/09/05/06-56-42-171_08fb6174b1755121.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989069},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"The Boys Season 2 Introduces the Show's Equivalent of Marvel's Hawkeye & Daredevil","link":"https://www.cbr.com/the-boys-season-2-hawkeye-daredevil/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/the-boys-daredevil-hawkeye-header.jpg\"/></figure><p><em><strong>WARNING: The following article contains major spoilers for the first three episodes of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-boys-tv/\">The Boys</a> Season 2, available now on Amazon Prime Video.</strong></em></p><p>As a deconstruction of superheroes, Amazon's <em>The Boys </em>features a lot of nod to the genre's most iconic figures. While DC is definitely the obvious target of <em>The Boys </em>deconstructionism -- with Homelander standing in for Superman and the Seven being a version of the Justice League -- the first three episodes of <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/boys-season-2-certified-fresh-rotten-tomatoes/\"><em>The Boys </em>Season 2</a> introduce the show's take on two big Marvel heroes: Clint Barton/Hawkeye and Matt Murdock/Daredevil.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-boys-jeffrey-dean-morgan-season-3-covid-19/\">The Boys: Jeffrey Dean Morgan's Season 3 Role May Not Happen Due to COVID-19</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/the-boys-key-art-2.jpg\"/></figure><p>The first of the two heroes is Eagle the Archer, who is from Cleveland, Ohio. Equipped with a bow and arrow, Eagle is clearly based on Clint Barton/Hawkeye, though one could certainly make the argument for Oliver Queen/Green Arrow. Still, the fact Eagle doesn't seem rich means he's a little bit closer to Hawkeye than he is Green Arrow.</p><p>The Deep meets Eagle after being arrested, with the latter bailing the former out. While the Deep doesn't recognize his savior, Eagle notes that they have, in fact, met several times in the past. Not being remembered upsets Eagle a bit, but he moves past those feelings quickly. Eagle then lets the Deep crash at his apartment. However, this is part of an attempt to bring him to the Church of the Collective.</p><p>Drawing comparison between himself and his new friend, Eagle reveals that he ran out of arrows during a hostage situation, which resulted in people dying. This caused him to hit rock bottom. Following that incident, Eagle joined the Church of the Collective. He introduces the Deep to Carol, his teacher, and over the course of the next two episodes the former member of the Seven goes on a psychological (as well as psychotropic) journey in hopes of redeeming himself.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-boys-why-homelander-threatened-stormfront/\">The Boys: The Reason Why Homelander Is Threatened by Stormfront's Arrival</a></span></p><figure><img src=\"https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/the-boys-key-art-1.jpg\"/></figure><p>As for the second hero, his name is Blindspot, and he appears when Ashley Barrett -- who has taken over for the deceased Madelyn Stillwell -- introduces him as a potential replacement for Translucent. Blindspot showcases his incredible acrobatic skills, and reveals that he's blind. The character is definitely meant to parallel Daredevil, who is essentially a blind ninja with incredible acrobatic skills. Blindspot even remarks that he's able to identify Homelander thanks to his \"super ears.\"</p><p>However, Homelander does not want someone with a disability on the Seven, and he resents that <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-boys-vought-propaganda-ad-season-2/\">Vought International</a> is trying to control his team. As a result of those feelings, Homelander smashes Blindspot's ears, rendering him deaf. While Blindspot seems unlikely to reappear in the foreseeable future, Homelander's choice to reject him directly leads to Stormfront being added to the Seven.</p><p>There is something of a double reference here in the name Blindspot, whether purposeful or not. Although there are a few different characters with the name in Marvel's and DC's comics, the most important version of Blindspot to know in this case is Sam Chung, who was created by Charles Soule and Ron Garney in 2015's <em>All-New, All-Different Marvel Point One</em> #1. A trained gymnast, Chung created an invisibility suit for himself and eventually teamed up with Daredevil. However, during a confrontation with the villain Muse, Chung was blinded, which set off a deadly chain of events involving The Hand, a group of villainous ninja.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-boys-honest-trailer-shades-disney-amazon/\">The Boys Honest Trailer Takes a Shot at Zack Snyder, Disney and Amazon</a></span></p><p>Overall, Eagle is much more likely to be important to <em>The Boys </em>Season 2 than Blindspot, seeing as the latter hero was pretty much immediately taken down by Homelander. For his part, Eagle's role in the Deep's recovery and what happens with the disgraced member of the Seven going forward isn't totally clear at this time. Still, the Church of the Collective very much looks like it could play a major role in <em>The Boys </em>Season 2.</p><p><em>Amazon Studios' <a href=\"https://screenrant.com/the-boys-season-2-3-comic-stories/amp/\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\">The Boys</a> stars Karl Urban as <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-boys-season-1-billy-butcher-recap/\">Billy Butcher</a>, Jack Quaid as Hughie, Laz Alonso as Mother's Milk, Tomer Kapon as Frenchie, Karen Fukuhara as the Female, Erin Moriarty as Annie January, Chace Crawford as the Deep, Antony Starr as Homelander, Aya Cash as Stormfront and Simon Pegg as Hughie's dad. New episodes of Season 2 release Fridays on Amazon Prime Video.</em></p><p><span class=\"next-single\">KEEP READING: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/the-boys-billy-butcher-baby-laser-tag-ar-game/\">The Boys Lets You Channel Billy Butcher With Baby Laser Tag AR Game</a></span></p>\n                        \n                        \n                    ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 04 Sep 2020 19:45:34 +0000","feedId":3746,"bgimg":"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/the-boys-daredevil-hawkeye-header.jpg","linkMd5":"865b394c22ecbda7497bdf31cab4191d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn6@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-31-863_64f38d670aaa9844.webp","destWidth":1400,"destHeight":700,"sourceBytes":176679,"destBytes":142238,"author":"Liam Nolan","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/the-boys-daredevil-hawkeye-header.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn6@2020_2/2020/09/05/06-56-31-863_64f38d670aaa9844.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/the-boys-key-art-2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn30@2020_1/2020/09/05/06-56-37-311_4c0866190efc8cc7.webp","https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/the-boys-key-art-1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn80@2020_4/2020/09/05/06-56-36-321_afdf020f91fc3104.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1599288989073},{"createdTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","updatedTime":"2020-09-05 14:56:29","title":"MCU: 5 Ways The Incredible Hulk Has Aged Well (& 5 Ways It Hasn't)","link":"https://www.cbr.com/mcu-the-incredible-hulk-aged-poorly-vs-remained-relevant/","description":"\n                        \n                        <figure><img src=\"https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/The-Incredible-Hulk-Featured-Image.jpg\"/></figure><p>Despite the troubles that happened behind the scenes, 2008's<em> <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/tag/the-incredible-hulk/\">The Incredible Hulk</a></em> was considered not only an improvement from the 2003 film but a really good introduction for this character into the Marvel Cinematic Universe. It definitely got fans interested to see where everyone's favorite angry green giant would go in the future of this series.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/incredible-hulk-vs-immortal-hulk-mcu/\">10 Differences Between The Incredible Hulk And The Immortal Hulk</a></span></p><p>Though it does have its fan and continues to be what many consider one of the more overlooked entries of the MCU that deserves a new sequel, it does feature some elements that have not aged as well since its theatrical debut over ten years ago.</p>\n                        <h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">10 </span>Incredible: The Main Cast</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/Bruce-And-Betty.jpg' /></figure><p>It is a shame that the drama occurred behind the scenes because Edward Norton, as always with every role, performed excellently as Bruce Banner throughout the film and likely would have been a great part of<em> <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/avengers-earths-mightiest-heroes-vs-assemble-best/\">The Avengers</a></em> cast. He made it believable that he was a genius but he also nailed the awkward yet charming side of Banner to make one feel for his plight.</p><p>The same can be said for the likes of Liv Tyler as <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-hulk-betty-ross-best-moments-ranked/\">Betty Ross</a>, William Hurt as General Ross, and the villain who steals the show in every scene that he's in. All put their own unique takes on these iconic characters while remaining loyal to the comics that spawned them.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">9 </span>Unfortunate: A Little Too Short</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/edward-norton-hulk.jpg' /></figure><p>Understandably, the movie wanted to be more action-packed to avoid the mistakes of the Ang Lee movie which many fans felt was too long and padded out thus making it a boring film. With<em> The Incredible Hulk</em>, it's essentially one long chase between Bruce Banner and General Ross's forces.</p><p>This chase works but it comes at a cost of a lot of the story beats and character-driven moments feeling rushed with little time to simmer for the audience before Banner has to get on the run again or Hulk has to smash something. The movie could have benefited from an extra ten to twenty minutes of runtime.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">8 </span>Incredible: The Duality Of Banner/Hulk</h2><figure><img src='https://static2.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Edward-Norton-the-Hulk.jpeg' /></figure><p>One of Stan Lee's biggest inspirations for the Hulk's creation was <em>Dr. Jekyll And Mr. Hyde</em> and it shows with Banner and Hulk being completely different beings who happen to share a body. This aspect was brought to the big screen rather well with Hulk's interactions with Betty and Banner's flashes of Hulk's memories.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/things-worldbreaker-hulk-can-do/\">Worldbreaker Hulk: 15 Things He Can Do That Regular Hulk Can't</a></span></p><p>Much like in this comics, it makes the viewer feel sympathy for both sides because one is a man who just wants to return to his normal life while the other is like a superpowered child experiencing everything for the first time. It's tragic and intriguing which is why Hulk is one of the most interesting Marvel characters.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">7 </span>Unfortunate: Forgettable Score</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/Liv-Tyler-as-Betty-Ross-from-The-Incredible-Hulk.jpg' /></figure><p>One common complaint fans have had throughout the many years of the Marvel Cinematic Universe is that other than <em>The Avengers</em> theme, <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/spider-man-best-villains-never-been-movie-ranked-spider-slayer-puma-chameleon/\">Spider-Man</a></em> theme, and a few select others, the orchestral score for the movies rarely have any memorable tracks and <em>The Incredible Hulk</em> is no different.</p><p>However, it does feature a well-done tribute to<em> The Incredible Hulk</em> TV series starring Bill Bixby and Lou Ferrigno and an okay overture, it's not a terrible score by any means. The composition is nice but there's no track that one will consider to be an iconic theme for the character.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">6 </span>Incredible: The Hulk Is, Indeed, Incredible</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/Incredible-Hulk.jpg' /></figure><p>The struggle of Bruce Banner, the chase sequences, the villain? All great things to enjoy but audiences come to a Hulk movie to see the Hulk destroy vehicles and look scary while doing so. Fans were not disappointed because every single time the Hulk appears on-screen, it is pure carnage candy with plenty of explosions, environmental weaponry, and a villain fight that wins the movie.</p><p>The Hulk's design is great as well, making him a much darker shade of green that, somehow, pops really well in all the very vibrantly lit scenes.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">5 </span>Unfortunate: Hulk Looks Nothing Like Banner</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/The-Incredible-Hulk.jpg' /></figure><p>This is an aspect that would be remedied with Mark Ruffalo's incarnation of the character in the first <em>Avengers</em> movie. In most cases, the Hulk is supposed to look like if Bruce Banner took too many steroids and jumped into a pool of green dye thus resulting in a caveman version of himself.</p><p><span class=\"related-single\">RELATED: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/every-incarnation-of-the-hulk-ranked/\">Every Incarnation Of The Hulk, Ranked</a></span></p><p>Well, in <em>The Incredible Hulk</em>, while his design overall is nice, the only issue fans have had with it is that the Hulk's face shares little to no similarities to Edward Norton. Even the hair magically changes lengths and facial hair vanishes when he's the Hulk for whatever reason.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">4 </span>Incredible: The Look And Tone Of The Movie Was Perfect</h2><figure><img src='https://static1.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2019/11/Edward-Norton-The-Incredible-Hulk-Featured.jpg' /></figure><p>As mentioned previously, this movie has a very vibrant look to it: the scenery and characters are all filmed with heavy contrast and brightness that's offset by the characters who all wear mostly dark clothes or, in the case of the monsters, have darker shades of skin compared to their comic book counterparts.</p><p>The movie's tone was also a healthy balance: when it needed to be dark and focus on the tragedy of the hero, it was. When it needed to be intense for action sequences, it was. It also added a healthy about of humor in there without going overboard.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">3 </span>Unfortunate: The Deleted Better Opening To The Movie</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2017/10/Incredible-Hulk-suicide-scene.jpg' /></figure><p>The opening credit sequence of the movie is completely lackluster: it's essentially a laughably shortened and silent version of the origin story that looks cheap and feels tacked on at the last second which would not be surprising since there was going to be a much better opening scene.</p><p>Originally it was going to open up with a dark and literally cold scene where Bruce attempts to commit suicide but it just results in a transformation into the other guy. This scene was mentioned in the first <em>Avengers</em> movie by <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-mcu-incredible-hulk-accurate-depiction/\">Mark Ruffalo's Banner.</a></p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">2 </span>Incredible: Abomination Was The MCU's First Great Villain</h2><figure><img src='https://static3.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/6401997-incredible-hulk-abomination-tim-roth-marvel-studios-1009669-1280x0.jpg' /></figure><p>Jeff Bridges' Obadiah Stane in <em><a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/iron-man-armors-mcu/\">Iron Man</a></em> was considered a decent villain but nothing special whereas even before getting transformed into a nasty monster, Tim Roth was an intimidating villain as Emil Blonsky. He was a spec-ops soldier who got hopped up on super-soldier serum and was determined to get back at the Hulk which is intriguing.</p><p>However, once he gets his taste for powers, his descent into madness throughout the movie is one of the more fascinating aspects of the movie and when he finally gets Banner's blood and becomes <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/abomination-the-10-weirdest-facts-about-the-hulks-strongest-villain/\">Abomination</a>, he's instantly one of the best things of the movie.</p><h2 class=\"item-title\"><span class=\"item-num\">1 </span>Unfortunate: Setup For More That Went Nowhere</h2><figure><img src='https://static0.cbrimages.com/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/The-Leader-1.jpg' /></figure><p>This movie acted as a great seed that should have bloomed into an entire franchise of movies about the Hulk but unfortunately, most of what they set up in this movie has yet to return in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. Abomination was still alive which meant that he could have been a perfect recurring threat for even the Avengers but not even a cameo in <em>Avengers: Endgame</em>.</p><p>Tim Blake Nelson's Samuel Sterns AKA The Leader has yet to even be mentioned again after his little tease for his transformation. Even Tony Stark's cameo at the end ended up being useless in the end since it's neither General Ross nor Stark that recruits Banner into the Avengers. Hopefully, this is rectified in <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/she-hulk-jennifer-walters-dream-casting-marvel-disney-plus-series/\">She-Hulk's solo series on Disney+</a>.</p><p><span class=\"next-single\">NEXT: <a href=\"https://www.cbr.com/marvel-she-hulk-better-worse-cousin-hulk/\">5 Ways She-Hulk Is Superior To Her Cousin (&#38; 5 Ways Hulk Is Still Incredible)</a></span></p>\n
